fields.title: Geofysiske og geokemiske undersøgelser i Itinneq - i forbindelse med vejprojektet mellem Sisimiut og Kangerlussuaq
fields.abstract:
From introduction:
Denne opgave omhandler forundersøgelser af
vejtraceet for den potentielle vej mellem
Sisimiut og Kangerlussuaq med fokus på da
len Itinneq ved fjorden Maligiaq, hvori el-
ven Oles Lakseelv er beliggende. Vejtraceet
er udarbejdet ud fra en topografisk model
baseret på orthofotos, som vejteknikere ha
r sammenholdt med kriterierne om, at vejen
skal være en to-sporet grusvej med
en normeret hastighed på 60 km/t.
Strækningen er på ca. 170 km og vil blive de
n første vejforbindelse mellem to beboede
områder i Grønland (se figur 1b). Sisimiut
er Grønlands næststørste by med 5500 ind-
byggere, beliggende på Grønlands vestkyst, me
ns Kangerlussuaq har Grønlands interna-
tionale lufthavn med direkte flyforbindelser til København og Baltimore. 
Gennem de seneste 10 år har
vejtraceet været udgangspunktet
for undersøgelserne i fel-
ten foretaget af forskere og studerende fr
a DTU. Undersøgelserne har været med hen-
blik på at opnå såvel detailkendskab til de
ofte svært tilgængelige områder, såvel som
kendskab til bjergarternes egenskaber og jord
typer i områder, hvor man forventer at der
kan være særlige problemer
med hensyn til vejbygning. Dermed
vil det være muligt at
give et kvalificeret bud på hvad det vil koste
at anlægge vejstrækningen, så beslutnings-
tagere i det grønlandske hjemmestyre og i
Sisimiut Kommune ha
r et udgangspunkt når
de diskuterer de samfundsøkonomiske fordel
e sammenholdt med prisen på projektet.

fields.title: Permafrost foundation in Thule
fields.abstract:
Several buildings at Thule Air Base have had severe
settlements. These settlements
have been caused by the thermal regimes and effects
from the specific buildings.
There has always been, and still is, great focus on
applied foundation methods in
Thule, and other areas with frost susceptible soils
in the Arctic. In general the thermal
balances of the soils are sought to be disturbed as
little as possible.
Buildings are wherever possible founded in order to
maintain ventilation beneath
the building; buildings are elevated on pillars and
pad foundations in the top of the
permanently frozen layers. The upper soil layers ar
e dozed of, and soils, that are
assumed to be non frost susceptible, are laid out i
n layers of typically
m
2 in depth.
This is done to avoid seasonal thaw, and in some ca
ses heat from the building, to
penetrate to the frost susceptible layers.
Severe settlement damages are seldom encountered wh
en buildings are elevated
above the soil surface, allowing for free cooling a
nd reduced radiation. However,
major damages on buildings with ventilated cooling
systems in, or underneath the
floor are often observed due to lack of maintenance
and operational flaws, together
with increased indoor temperatures. This contribute
s to a rapidly accelerating series of
settlement damages on the floor, as well as the str
uctural integrity of the building.
This has necessitated an increasing amount of repai
r of the buildings.
In this report the settlement situation of the Vehi
cle Maintenance facility at Thule Air
Base will be assessed. Since its construction in 19
56, the building has had differential
settlements reaching approximately
cm
75 . A study of previous geotechnical
investigations conducted in the facility has been m
ade, and a collection of new
geotechnical and geophysical data has been made. Th
ese investigations are compared
and evaluated with each other and the “General Plan
– Thule Air Base” in order to
give a recommendation for the repair options the fl
oor in the facility.
The investigations included a boring in the area of
the building with the largest
settlements. Soil samples have been gathered from t
his boring in order to examine the
water content and grain size distribution. The resu
lt of this has shown a high water
content, and that the soil is poorly graded, contai
ning a higher amount of fines than
what should be expected of a non frost susceptible
soil. Investigations of the
accessible air ducts in the floor have showed that
the ducts contain large amounts of
unfrozen water with positive temperatures in the ar
ea of the largest settlements, which
hinders the intended air cooling in the ducts. The
settlements lead to leaks of water
and fluids in the disrupted air ducts. All of this
leads to a change in the thermal
balance, and as the soil is more frost susceptible
than assumed in the design, the
tolerance of the thermal disrupts decreases accordi
ngly.
Measurements using Ground Penetrating Radar, GPR, h
ave been conducted near the
facility in order to map the depths to the permanen
tly frozen layers, which were found
in depths of
2
to
m
5.2 below ground surface.
Furthermore we performed GPR measurements below Han
gar 8, which was
repaired and founded on pillars and pads in 1996 du
e to severe settlement damages as
a consequence of a thawing of the underlying soils.
These measurements were made
in order to map the depth of the previously thawed
layers. The profiles indicate a 
previous thaw depth of
6 to
m
8 which correlates well with the calculations and
assumptions made in connection with the repair of t
he hangar
Measurements with GPR were also conducted on an ar
tificial lake, Lake Eddy, near
the runway, and in an area between South Mountain a
nd DET-3. The measurements
on the lake were conducted to evaluate the depth of
the lake, and whether or not the
sediments on the bottom of the lake were frozen or
thawed. The area near DET-3 was
studied to find clear indications of how ice wedges
and patterned ground are reflected
in the radargram. This was done since the original
topography on base has been dozed
of, and features such as these might still be prese
nt underneath the fill laid out in
connection with construction of the base. It is of
general interest to find out whether
GPR can be used in areas of similar geology and cli
mate as Thule in order to detect
ice bodies.
Hand calculations have been included to calculate t
he expected depth of the active
layer, maximum thaw depth underneath Vehicle Mainte
nance in the design situation,
as well as the present situation of a
C
°
5 warmer inside temperature. To understand
the settlements the lowest acceptable wind speed in
the air ducts has been calculated.
Furthermore the consequence of the thaw depth when
a number of the cooling ducts
covering
m
10 are out of function has been calculated. The calc
ulations showed that
the increase of the inside temperature alone is not
causing the settlements, but the
importance of the correct operation of cooling duct
s is illustrated by the calculations.
Temperature modellings have also been performed in
the program TEMP/W.
TEMP/W is a finite element program that is capable
of computing the development of
temperature distributions in soils based on constan
t temperatures or temperature flows
at a given boundary. It is also possible to include
climate data in TEMP/W models.
Three models have been created; the first one to cl
arify how long a freeze up of the
thawed soil will take with the establishment of fre
e ventilation under the building. The
second model computes the steady state situation if
cooling pipes with a constant
temperature of
C
°
−
5 were to be installed in every second air duct. Th
e third model
calculates the maximum thaw depth, if a number of t
he air ducts covering
m
10 are
out of function. The last model is made for compari
son of the hand calculation with a
model that includes the latent heat of water, which
clearly has an influence. Generally
the models show a good relationship with the experi
ences documented at Thule Air
Base.
Overall the conclusions and recommendations of this
study was that:
•
Thermal balance of soils should be kept as undistur
bed as possible.
•
Free ventilation under buildings should be used whe
rever possible.
•
Secure that cooling ducts are properly maintained a
nd operated.
•
Establish artificial cooling with cooling pipes whe
never ventilated
cooling ducts show signs of malfunction.
•
Due to foreseen changes in climate with an increase
in mean
annual temperature and precipitation, the active la
yer will increase
in depth, in some places exceeding the non frost su
sceptible fill.
However, due to the placement of Thule Air Base so
far north, it is
less vulnerable compared to other locations in Gree
nland.

fields.title: Planlægning af kostundersøgelse i Grønland
fields.abstract:
Allergy is an increasing issue both in the developing countries as well as the western 
areas and this condition is expected to be associated with environmental conditions 
rather than genetic factors. The allergic status is defined by the concentration of specific 
immunoglobulin E (IgE) in the blood. It is hypothesized that an intake of a high n-3/n-6 
ratio in the diet causes a lowering of the allergic rate, i.e. the content of IgE in the blood. 
In a screening study it is indicated that the intake of marine fat is enhanced in Greenland 
as related to Denmark and this make a potential relation easier to detect. For this reason 
the study is conducted in Greenland. 
The aim of this project is to design a proper study from which it is possible to 
detect a relation between the n-3/n-6 ratio in the diet and the IgE content in the blood. 
Endeavour has been made to optimize the statistical accuracy in respect to financial and 
practical issues. 
The study is carried out in Sisimiut, which is the second largest town in 
Greenland. The volunteers in the study are collected based on an advertising campaign 
and the sample size is estimated to consist of at least 4 persons. They are interviewed 
about their diet in order to estimate the n-3/n-6 ratio in their diet and blood samples are 
collected with the objective to estimate the content of specific IgE in the blood. 
The n-3/n-6 ratio is a univariate response where as the IgE content is a 
multivariate response. As a possible statistical analysis, principal components are found 
for the IgE content and each of these vectors is related to the n-3/n-6 ratio in order to 
sort out a possible relationship.

fields.title: Kemiske vandanalyser
fields.abstract:
Fra introduktion:
Specialkurset
Kemiske vandanalyser
har foregået i perioden 1. februar-1. september 2006
under vejledning af professor Ar
ne Villumsen, og Bente Fryden
lund, tidligere laborant på
Center for Arktisk Teknologi (ARTEK), Danmar
ks Tekniske Universitet (DTU). Kurset har
virket som forberedelse på det laboratoriea
rbejde, som er nødvendigt til analysear i
forbindelse med forfatterens
afgangsprojekt, skrevet i efteråret 2006.
Denne rapport omhandler de analyse- og ar
bejdsmetoder, som blev gennemgået i kurset.
Endvidere vises et par eksemplarer på resultater
af analyser lavet på to drikkevandsprøver;
den ene taget i Sisimiut, primo februar 2006 og
den anden på ARTEK, DTU den 9. februar
2006. I første afsnit,
Analyse- og arbejdsmetoder,
bliver analyse- og arbejdsmetoder
gennemgået, bl.a. prøvetagning og opbevaring
af prøver, målinger på pH, ledningsevne,
alkalinitet og ionkoncentrationer. Herefter gennemgås resultater fra analyserne i afsnittet
Resultater
og i det sidste afsnit,
Diskussion,
bliver de to prøver ho
ldt op mod hinanden, og
de fundne værdier sammenlignet med grænse
værdier fra EU ́s drikkevandsdirektiv og
Bekendtgørelse om vandkvalitet og
tilsyn med vandforsyningsanlæg,
nr. 871 af 21.09.2001
(herefter kaldt Bekendtgørelse nr. 871)

fields.title: Solstråling under arktiske forhold
fields.abstract:
Throughout this project, solar radiation and its reflection under Arctic conditions has been of main focus. A wide specter of parameters, with possible influences on the ground-reflected radiation has been investigated throughout this project.
The project has been separated into a theoretical analysis of the existing data material and a correction of this material. This adjustment has been carried out on the foundation of experimental work performed in Greenland.
The theoretical analysis includes an investigation of data sets from two years of measurement performed at a climate station located in Sisimiut, Greenland. A definition of irradiance level linked to the uncertainty of the horizon screening has been carried out and further, a definition of periods with ground-coverage of snow and no snow-coverage has been performed. This has formed the background for an evaluation of the influence of solar height as well as the position of the sun, with respect to ground-reflected radiation under the conditions of snow-coverage and no snow-coverage. A theoretical evaluation of the view factor from the pyranometer to the ground has been performed, to encircle the relevant area where detailed mapping of the terrain was required.
The adjustment of the existing data material was carried out on basis of a terrain mapping performed in Greenland, followed by construction of maps illustrating the formation of shadows. With the knowledge of the theoretical view factor and the proportion of shadows on the ground at a known solar height and position of the sun, the albedo (reflection coefficient) for ground-reflected radiation has been adjusted. This resulted in an increase of the reflection coefficient.
This project has resulted in a greater understanding of solar radiation under Arctic conditions. A great potential for utilization of the solar energy under these conditions has been found, despite the dark winter periods.
After this work has finished, several lessons have been learned and it is advised, that considerations are made by placing, for instance a solar collector, to get the optimum utilization of the solar energy. The topography of the surrounding terrain has great influence on the amount of reflected radiation, and especially the type of ground-coverage holds great influence. It has been found, that the proportion of reflected radiation by ground-coverage of snow can reach up to 80 %, while the proportion of reflected radiation at no snow-coverage accounts for approx. 20 %.
Substantial amounts of precipitation are seen under Arctic conditions, and this should be taken into consideration as well, as the proportion of reflected radiation is changed considerably from fresh snow to aged snow.
In the view of the analyses carried out in this report, it is made possible to obtain an overview of the prerequisites that holds importance in order to achieve optimal utilization of the solar energy. It is necessary to mention, that in order to obtain a complete overview of utilization of solar energy under Arctic conditions, further and in-depth analyses, on basis of this fundamental knowledge, should be carried out.

fields.title: Udledning af fiskerispildevand ved Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
This project evolves around the fjord north of Sisimiut in Greenland. Since the common
practice in Greenland is to discharge untreated wastewater directly into the recipient, this
is exactly how it is done by Royal Greenland to the fjord north of Sisimiut.
Studies of the currents and exchange of water between the inner and outer fjord showed
that the exchange is limited and that the tidal induced currents lacks the energy to
transport sediments. Analysis of sediment samples showed increased concentrations of
the heavy metals, cadmium and to some degree cupper. The content of organic matter,
nutrients and sulfur in the sediment samples indicates frequent occurrences of oxygen
depletion in the sediment. Based on these results it was concluded that the fjord is
affected in a negative way by the current discharges.
Since there is no law in Greenland concerning discharge of untreated wastewater the
solution has to be attractive to Royal Greenland in terms of economy. Ideally the
expenses should not exceed the earnings. During the analysis of the fjord it was
recognized that the discharge from the hospital and the general public also is a major
contributor to the pollution in the fjord. Therefore the solution chosen is the production of
biogas, since this makes it possible to treat some of the wastewater from this other point
source along with the wastewater from Royal Greenland.
To determine the possibility of producing biogas using the wastewater from Royal
Greenland, the material in Sisimiut, available for the process, was evaluated in regards to
weather there is potential for producing biogas. Potential was established. It is
recommended that the shells of the shrimps are separated during or after producing
biogas. Hereby the possibilities of extracting chitin, chitosan, astaxanthin are still present.
