Reflektionsseismisk og mikropalæontologiske undersøgelse af Første Fjorden, Sisimiut, Grønland
fields.abstract:
The project carried out in Førstefjorden (Kangerluarsuk Tulleq) near the city of Sisimiut, 
Greenland was done in July and August of 2004 in association with the Technical 
University of Denmark. The aim of the project was to obtain an understanding of the 
geological settings of the area, by means of shallow reflection seismics and 
micropalaeontological sampling. During the acquisition of seismic data, both a single 
channel streamer and a 12-channel streamer was used. The source was a high frequency 
boomer (400-8000 Hz). The geological interpretation has been carried out using the data 
from the single channel streamer, whereas the purpose of using the 12-channel streamer 
was to find out if it is possible to improve the signal/noise ratio. 
Førstefjorden is an inlet dominated by former ice coverage during which the glaciers have 
eroded into the substrate; however the sediments present in the area have been deposited 
during and after the retreat of the ice, and do possibly consist of glacial moraines and post 
glacial marine sediments. It has also been possible to determine some of the depositional 
environments and some of the resulting structures of the fiord. 
From the micropalaeontological data it was possible to establish an understanding of the 
environmental parameters affecting the innermost part of the fiord today and in addition to 
this to determine regions of strong current and coarser material

fields.title: Reflektionsseismisk og mikropalæontologiske undersøgelse ved vandløb i Ikertoq og Amerdloq, Sisimiut, Grønland
fields.abstract:
This study was carried out in two fjords near the town of Sissimiut, Western Greenland. The
purpose of the research was to determine if there was any occurences of coarsegrained sedimentary
materials in connection with freshwater outflows in two smaller bays. The methods used, was high
resolution seismics and micropaleaontological samples taken from the sea floor. In the nothernmost
area of intrest, two particular sediment bodies has been described in detail. The sediments are
deposited in strong interaction with the significant tidal currents found in the fjords of this area. In
the other area in the fjord of Ikertoq two interfingering deltas has been mapped on the seismics. One
larger created by the daily flows of tidal currents moving over a low, narrow threshold, and one
made by a river outlet in the western side of the bay, but with a high degree of resedimentation by
the tidal currents. The micropaleoontological data reveals a fauna wich is highly influenced by the
extreme living conditions in the bay areas, in regards to temperature (artic water), amount of
suspended material in the water, salinity and powerfull currents. The general fauna composition in
the examined areas are very much alike in some respects, as there is a general trend in a high
number of agglutinated species and the living to dead ratio is low. This is interpreted to be the case
in most relative shallow water areas in the inner parts of fjords in this environment. There is also
seen different faunal assemblages within each of the two studied areas, wich indicates highly
varying sedimentary environments.

fields.title: Stikvej til Safannguaq - En vurdering af mulighederne
Vand i jord under arktiske forhold
fields.abstract:
The main subject of this project is water in soil and rock. The purpose is to create an overview concerning where and how water is located in soils and rocks. Methods to detect water in rock and soils, prevent landslides and stabilize cohesive soils are also studied. The stabilization methods are also commented in regards to their use under arctic conditions.
Methods to detect water in soils mentioned in this report are the use of georadar, seismic and neutron logging.
The landslide stabilization methods described are; treatment of the slope shape by adding or reducing soil load on the bottom or top of the slope, drainage (surface and subsurface), vegetation, retaining walls, rock bolts and steel nets.
Methods mentioned in the stabilization of cohesive soils are stabilization by addition of lime/cement, fly ash and magnesium hydroxide.
It is concluded that most of the landslide stabilization methods can be used under artic conditions. Though would stabilization by vegetation probably not have any effect. It is also concluded that stabilization of cohesive soils by addition of lime/cement and fly ash should be effective in the artic region. Stabilization by magnesium hydroxide would on the other hand be ineffective in the arctic.

fields.title: Elektroosmose - afvanding af forskellige sedimenter
fields.abstract:
It has been tested how well electro-osmosis works on sediments wtih a very large faction of clay and and sediments with a little faction of clay.
Electro-osmosis is movement of water caused by an electric field. When an field of direct current is enforced on a porous medium electro-osmosis will take place. Furthermore is an electric double-layer is required. Clay particles have a negative charged surface. To maintain the balance of charge, positive ions from the fluid will added to the clay particles. Thereby an electrical double-layer is created. The ions which lay closely to the clay surface will cause the movement of water. In the bulk phase there is the same amount of positive and negative ions, and therefore these will not have an effect on the movement of water.
3 different kinds of samples were used to the tests. 2 with a high content of clay and one with a high content of sand.
The samples were put in plastic cylinders, which were closed with rubber corks. In one of the corks there was a hole, so the water could get out. Furthermore steel wool was placed in both ends of the cylinder between the sample an cork. Two thin iron sticks were nipped round to the steel wool. Next, direct current was applied and there was made a note the amount of fluid dripped form the samples every fifth minute.
As expected electro-osmosis worked very well on sediments with a high faction of clay. It was the other way around with sediments almost clay free.
Also you could see, that a higher clay faction caused a smaller resistance in the samlpe.
From the results, you can conclude that electro-osmosis do not work on sediments with a large faction of sand, but works very well on sediments with a clay faction on 66 weight percent or above.
It has not been possible to state a clear limit for how much clay there has to bee in a sample, before electro-osmosis can be used.

fields.title: Tungmetalforureningens omfang i Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
In this report, the first thing investigated is the difference between Greenlandic and Danish clay.
This report concludes that the adsorptive capability, with regards to Cd and Pb, is lesser for the Greenlandic clay than it is for the Danish. However, the difference is relatively smaller than expected prior to test start. CEC-values of the 2 clays is not far apart either. The Danish clay has a calculated CEC-value of 12,4 meq/100 g DW, while the CEC-value of the Greenlandic clay is 9,1 meq/100 g DW.
On basis of these results, it is concluded that the wash out of heavy metals into the sea, is greater in Greenland when compared to Denmark.
Following, an attempt is made to list the degree of Cd -and Pb pollution in Sisimiut, Greenland for potentially contaminated sites.
The pollution in Sisimiut is at an acceptable level, since most of the soil- and sediment samples are below the quality criteria for soil, defined by Miljøestyrelsen.
On the dump, there is as expected, a heavily polluted sample 8(J5), with a Cd-concentration of 27 mg/kg and a Pb concentration of 1174 mg/kg, below the big-bags containing fly-ash.
These concentrations exceed the cut off criteria defined by Miljøministeriet. Requirements are necessary and the soil is to be cut off from contact with humans.
5 other samples have a level of pollution, which requires closer investigations and extended public surveillance.
This concerns sample 7(J4) polluted with Cd, taken by the big-bags filled with fly-ash.
The other 4 samples, which is polluted with Pb, is taken from an active shipyard 16(J20), a passive dump 17(J21), a passive tank establishment 18(J22) and an abandoned shrimp/prawn- and fishfactory 19(J23).
The problem concerning pollution on the Dump in Sisimiut, can be solved by removing the big-bags filled with fly-ash. However, since problems concerning the disposal are still unsolved, it is relevant to investigate alternative ways of disposing the fly-ash with the high contents of Cd and Pb.
This has led to investigate the opportunity of electrodialytic removal of Cd and Pb from the fly-ash.
From the results in the electrodialytic experiment, it is concluded that it is possible to remove Cd and Pb from the fly-ash. Due to the low recovery, 54% for Cd and 42% for Pb, the efficiency of the removal is subject to discussion. An interval of efficiency, concerning the removal of Cd and Pb, is indicated, in which the low recovery is taken into consideration. The interval of efficiency for Cd is [51%-95%] and [31%-71%] for Pb.
From these intervals of efficiency, it is concluded that using electrodialytic extraction on flyash, Cd is more easily removed than Pb.
The electrodialytic remediation method used for removal of heavy metals from the Sisimiut fly-ash is still on a need to know-basis and further investigations are required to evaluate the efficiency of the method for a more permanent solution concerning the pollution of heavy metals on the dump.

fields.title: Vejbygning i områder med permafrost
fields.abstract:
Sisimiut are considering the construction of a road connecting the harbour in Sisimiut with 
the airport in Kangerlussuaq. The road will cover a total distance of 170 km of which 14 
km already exists. The purpose of this project is to describe the construction of road in 
correlation with permafrost and the experience already known to the construction of roads 
in areas with permafrost. Information about the area is from students’ projects from
Arktek, DTU and a report from Sisimiut. This project is not a cost analysis but gives a 
solution to the establishment of a road on permafrost between Sisimiut and Kangerlusuaq. 
The road is to be placed on the edge of the Nagssugtoqidian Mobile Belt with the Archean 
Block to the south. The Nagssugtoqidian Mobile Belt consists mostly of gneiss in 
amphibolites facies. The ice sheet has several times covered the area. The last ended 6.000 
to 5.000 years ago and it moved to its known position today. The retreat of the ice caused 
an isostatic heave of the area and marine sediments are found at maximum height at 
Utoqqaat at 140 meters. At Sisimiut the marine sediments have its maximum height at 100 
meters and at Kangerlussuaq it is 60 meters. The marine sediments consists of sand and silt 
in a graded composition. Above the marine limit the sediments are glacial deposits and 
consists of not very well graded sand and gravel with some portion of finer material. At the 
melt rivers mouth there are well graded material such as sand, silt, clay and gravel. Both 
the marine and glacial deposits are assumed to be frost sensitive. The roadbed along the 
route consists of: 40 % gneiss, 30 % glacial sediments, 25 % marine sediments and the last 
5 % are metasediments and organic deposits.

fields.title: Forundersøgelser på Akia
fields.abstract:
Sisimiut has more than 5000 inhabitants and the city still grows in population. At
this time Sisimiut is running low on free building areas, and considering the future it has
been decided to make use of an area north of the present city called Akia to comply with
the newcomers.
The local authority has made a development plan containing the future building of
Akia. The first area to be build on is area A18, the buildings is planned to be flats and
family houses. The preliminary examinations of A18 have already begun, and the
building is to be launched in the spring of 2005.
This project contains an examination and evaluation of area A18, A19 and C14 in
different aspects. The project includes preliminary studies using electrical geophysics,
geotechnical drillings and laboratory experiments, and rock mechanics. Furthermore a
general view of the geological structure is made. In the light of these examinations and
testings the present building plan is considered.
It is concluded that the rock surface over large areas is of bad quality. The
underlying rock however his of good quality and for that reason the conclusion is that it
causes no problems to build on the rock. It may be necessary to remove the top part of the
rock in case of bad quality rock surface.
The soil contains layers that can cause problems in relation to constructions situated
directly on the ground. The soil contains marine clay, minor areas of permafrost and
layers that cause problems related to freezing and thawing. The depth to the bedrock is
difficult to establish, and supplementary drillings should be made.
As a consequence it is recommended not to place roads in the valleys if possible. If
roads are placed in the valleys, it is recommended to build gravel roads. They are easy
and cheap to maintain.
Considering building of houses, most of them are planned to be placed directly onto the
rock according to the development plan of A18. This will cause no problems. According
to the plan one or two buildings are placed in soil areas. But it shouldn’t be a problem to
reach solid rock underneath the chosen soil area. Either by digging away the dirt or reach
the rock ground with pylons.
The project includes an examination of an area on which a student hostel is to be
built. From a geological inspection and Schmidthammer surveys it is concluded that the
area consists of rock of very good quality. Considering this it is recommended to build
the hostel directly on the rock. This will cause no problems.

fields.title: Strømforhold i ralation til udledning af spildevand i to grønlandske byer - Sisimiut og Ilulissat
fields.abstract:
The common practice in Greenland is to discharge untreated waste water from the fishing 
industry directly into the sea. The purpose of this report is to investigate the relations between 
current pattern and waste water transport to determine if there is any connection to nutrient and 
heavy metal pollution in Sisimiut and Ilulissat. 
To determine the extent of the impact of the waste water discharge in the marine environment, 
sediment and water samples where collected at site and later analysed for the presence of heavy 
metals and nutrients. The hydrography of the coast has been studied by conducting CTDmeasurements, but a defect in the gauge makes the results a subject to uncertainty. The study 
will also include an evaluation of the importance of tidal induced currents. 
In Ulkebugten in the Sisimiut area high concentrations of nutrients and relatively high 
concentrations of heavy metals has been detected. As expected a large content of organic matter 
in the sediments coincide with high levels of heavy metals. Ulkebugten is a sill fjord and outside 
of the sill a wastewater discharge from the fishing industry is present. High velocities of tidal 
induced currents are expected across the sill in contrast to very low velocities at the wastewater 
discharge and at locations inside of the fjord. Waste water from 600 households and the local 
hospital is discharged to the fjord and it is difficult to determine how much of the pollution that 
originates from here. The CTD-measurements suggests that the rate of renewal of the waters 
inside the fjord is low. This may lead to an accumulation of particles from the waste water inside 
of the fjord. Deficient information of the conditions between the Royal Greenland discharge and 
the sill makes it impossible to eliminate the idea that the Royal Greenland discharge is a subject 
to heavy metal transport into the fjord. As long as the household waste water is discharged into 
the fjord, it is difficult to prove that fishing industry waste water has no effect on the conditions 
of Ulkebugten. It is therefore recommended to evaluate the options of moving the dischange 
point. 
Just outside of the entrance of the Ilulissat harbour fishing industry waste water is also 
discharged. The harbour of Ilulissat is disfigured by sludge, consisting of organic material which 
under decomposition produces obnoxious smelling hydrogen sulphides. The organic material is 
in large parts present in the inner parts of the harbour. The tidal induced currents are too weak to 
transport organic material from the discharge point of the waste water. It is estimated the 
shipping traffic has a great impact of the currents of the outer harbour and that suspended 
material entering the inner harbour with these currents will be accumulated in the inner harbour. 
This is due to the fact that only small boats make use of the inner harbour and that they do not 
create as large waves as the larger ships. Apart form the esthetical problem very high 
concentrations of heavy metals have been found. The higher concentrations cannot be explained 
by a different background concentration, as the Ilulissat values are up to 65 % higher than 
detected in Sisimiut. The heavy metals probably originate from the shipping industry and a 
defunct boat workshop, but the fishing industry waste water also contains cadmium in particular. 
The heavy metal concentrations entail that the sludge cannot be dumped at sea to eliminate the 
smell of hydrogen sulphide. Dumping the sediment only solves the problem temporarily and it is 
recommended to remove the discharge point to a place where the organic material is not 
transported inward.

fields.title: Vandkraftpotentialet i Vestgrønland
fields.abstract:
Most of Greenland’s hydroelectric power potentials are located in western Greenland. By 
far the largest potentials are located at the margin of the Greenland Ice. Energy intensive 
industries can with advantage be located here as well as hydroelectric power plants 
producing hydrogen for use in fuel-cells. The studies show a clear tendency; the ablation 
from the ice sheet to the Tasersiaq basin varies with the temperature and the accumulation. 
It has been estimated that the Greenland Ice sheet has to redraw 15-20 km. not to 
contribute to the hydro power potential of Tasersiaq. However this will probably take more
than 500 years. The smaller potentials in the ice free and inhabitable coast land are also of 
interest. Research shows that 2 households in Sdr. Igaliku can cover their yearly energy 
consumptions from local hydroelectric power. The obtainable production average an 
amount of 340 MWh a year. The initial cost of the power station will be around 730.000 
kr. This hydroelectric power station is able to produce electricity at 0,26 kr./kWh compared 
with the existing price of 2,26 kr./kWh and the time of refundment is estimated to be 
around 10,5 year. The profitability is thereby obviously good in connection with single 
households in western Greenland. Further research shows potential for the use of 
hydroelectric power in Sarfannguaq. The obtainable production average an amount of 306 
MWh a year. The initial cost of the power station will be around 3,3 mio. kr. which grants 
a price of 0,31 kr./kWh and the time of refundment will then be around 5 year. The
profitability is thereby good in connection with settlements in western Greenland. Trends 
in Communities in Greenland show that hydroelectric power in near future will be more
competitive in comparison to fossil fuels. Among the advantages using hydroelectric 
power are social, educational and environmental benefits. Inversely hydroelectric power
demands high initial investments and unintended effects on the ecosystem.

fields.title: Spildevand i Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
In Greenland there is no tradition for treating wastewater before discharge to a recipient. The 
scope of this project is therefore to look at a specific discharge point of wastewater in Sisimiut 
to evaluate the consequences of this discharge to the local environment. Furthermore possible 
methods for treating wastewater in cold regions are examined. This has lead to establishment 
of a pilot plant, which is based on infiltration in a peat leachfield. 
The discharge of wastewater in Sisimiut occurs in a fiord (Ulkebugten), which has great 
impact of the diffusion that is obtainable for wastewater. The water exchange in the fiord
happens at a rate so that the components in the discharged wastewater have a possibility to 
deposite. To avoid accumulation of nutrients and heavy metals in marine sediments 
resuspension is required. The velocities of the tidal currents in Ulkebugten are not 
sufficiently large to resuspend the sediments. This is supported by the distribution of nutrients 
and heavy metals, which indicates an accumulation of compounds from the discharge of
wastewater in the sediment. It is indicated that the fiord environment is suffering from the 
discharge of wastewater. The tidal currents outside Ulkebugten are examined concerning the 
possibility of placing the discharge of wastewater somewhere else. It is seen that the tidal
currents are strong enough for a discharge of wastewater west of Teleøen in Sisimiut. This
will not reduce the amount of discharged compounds within the wastewater, it will only be 
diluted. The optimal solution is to clean the wastewater before discharge to the recipients.

fields.title: Drikkevandskvalitet i Sisimiut kommune
fields.abstract:
Investigations of the drinking water quality in Sisimiut community have been carried out. All places with settlements in the community have been taken in to the examination. This covers 4 places: Sisimiut, Sarfannguaq, Kangerlussuaq and Itilleq. Water samples has been collected and to analyse the water quality at the consumer, at tap houses, in the distribution net and from places where the water is collected for the water supply, like lakes, wells or rivers.
The water samples has been analysed for chemical, physical and bacteriological parameters. The parameters have been chosen from typical parameters in a water quality investigation in Denmark and EU.
Individual evaluations of each sample has been carried out and compared with samples from the region and a sample from Denmark.
The treatment of water for supply in Sisimiut community is changing to whether it is a town or a small settlement (called bygder). The water supply in Sisimiut is abstracted from a waterlake (vandsø) in a commonly used area for recreation and for passage in winter. The lake is very vulnerable to contaminants and is therefore treated with addition of chlorine before send to the consumer. The export of food demands that the water used for cleaning and processing food has been treated with chlorine. There is a demand on 0.1 mg/L of chlorine in the furthest end of the distribution net.
In Sarfannguaq the water supply is also abstracted from a waterlake. Here the only treatment is filtering before distribution to the consumer. In Itilleq the water supply is a combination of water abstracted from a well and from the ocean. The water from the ocean is treated in an osmotic process for desalinisation. The only other treatment of the drinking water, in Itilleq apart from the osmotic process, is filtering. In Kangerlussuaq the water is abstracted from a waterlake and stored in large tanks, where it is chlorinated and filtered. After this treatment the water is driven to the consumers in trucks with large water tanks and delivered to tanks near households. The tanks give good growth conditions for bacteria.
An investigation of the liking of the drinking water quality in Sisimiut town showed a general discontent with the water quality in the distribution net due to smell and taste of chlorine. This made several consumers collect their own drinking water from lakes or rivers, before the water was treated.
Results from the water samples showed that generally the ion content in the water is very low compared to Danish standards. The only difference from this was Itilleq where water from the ocean influenced the ion content and also the fact that the water was abstracted from a well, lead to a higher ion content, conductivity and alkalinity and lead to a lower pH.
The water quality in Sisimiut community was frequently controlled by Nukissiorfiit (The Energy supplier) and evaluated in regard to the Danish and European standards, due to the export of food to European countries.
As Denmark and Greenland is two very different places in regards to geology, geographical and hydrological, a discussion whether these to places should have the same standards for water quality can be brought up. As the consumer of water in households is displeased with the water quality it could be an idea to set up parameters adapted to the special arctic conditions by having a lower or none at all chlorination. This would demand a separate distribution net to the food processing places or special directives/demands for arctic areas for food export. It would also require constantly control with the water in the distribution net to make certain no pollution is occurring that could be health risky.
To resume the water quality in Sisimiut community showed low concentration of ions and bacteria even without chlorination. It seems there is the possibility to make different demands for the chlorination according to arctic conditions, perhaps following season variations. Further investigations of the variations over the year have to be carried out to make a final evaluation.

fields.title: Grundvand i Sisimiut, Grønland
fields.abstract:
This project has been carried out after tree weeks of fieldwork in Sisimiut,
Greenland. The initial project was to find groundwater near the town, so that the
present water supply, which now is build on surface water from lake 5 could be
replaced. In the mean time, we soon faced the truth that this was not possible.
The permafrost was widely spread out. Instead we turned the project into
describing the geology and the permafrost in two areas of the catchments area of
lake 5. To do this we used geophysics methods, (MEP, seismic, georadar),
chemical surveys and of course the boreholes drilling.
In general it was found that the permafrost is very common and an obstacle in
finding groundwater. In a single area it was found that there wasn’t any
permafrost. This could have the reason that there were high concentrations of
salt, isolations from the nearby sea 4 or the presence of a talik.
In the rest of the area there was identified an active layer with a thickness between
0.4 and 3.0. Beneath the active layer the permafrost exists, which is exists all the
way down to the bedrock. The bedrock is found in a depth between 13 and 17 m.
After the comparison with previous surveys there were indications that the areas
with permafrost have become smaller. This can make the a rea appropriate for
abstraction of groundwater in the longer terms.

fields.title: Bedømmelse af fjeldkvalitet i Sisimiut og Utoqqaat – i forbindelse med fjeldrums- og vejkonstruktion
fields.abstract:
This assignment is aimed at giving an assessment of the rock quality in selected areas in Sisimiut and Utoqqaat in West Greenland. The rock mechanical parameters of the area, is evaluated trough both dynamic in-situ tests, and static laboratory work. The dynamic parameters are determined by the velocity of the direct and refracted sound waves in the rock mass. These are correlated with rebound height measurements and thereby expanded to a larger geographic area. The static parameters are determined by uniaxial
compression tests and point load tests in order to support the assessed in-situ parameters.
In Sisimiut two sites related to the proposed underground swimming bath project were subjected to seismic surveys.
The first site, "Stejlfjeldet", was investigated with vectoral seismic methods. These enable the determination of both P-wave and S-wave velocity, from which the Poisson’s ratio, Young’s
modulus and an estimation of the
Q-value for the top layer can be derived. The parameters obtained show that in this area the rock is not suitable for constructions. However, refraction seismics and a borehole from the valley below suggest that at higher depths the rock is more intact and an excavation of a cave could be undertaken.
Another site proposed for the project, named “Svømmehalsområdet”, was investigated with refraction seismics in two perpendicular directions to produce a complete picture of the
condition of the rock mass. However, a tomographic analysis was not performed, and thus the investigation only yielded P-wave velocities from the top layer. Outside the mayor faults these show similarities to those obtained from the borehole next to “Stejlfjeldet”. The Q-
value assessed from the P-wave velocity suggests, that as long as kept outside those faults, a cave could be excavated here.
In Utoqqaat two geologically different areas was investigated to estimate
their suitability for road construction. The planned road between Sisimiut and Kangerlussuaq has to rise to a higher altitude in this area an
d these two alternatives are considered to bring it up there. The
one area is a canyon consisting of meta-sediments with poor rock quality, and the other a steeper and wider passage over a gneiss outcrop.
Sound velocities in the meta-sediments are generally low confirming poor rock quality.
Refraction seismics show a layer of 5-10 m of weathered rock with low strength parameters
followed by unweathered rock with better properties. The gneiss outcrop on the other hand
shows good rock properties from the rebound measurements and laboratory tests.
The poor quality of the metasediments, combined with scree soils makes the passage through
the canyon problematic. The gneiss passage is more straight-forward, but the extensive rock
excavation necessary makes that al
ternative expensive. If the problems in the canyon could be
overcome in a reasonable way both economically and constructively, that route is
recommended
The surveys undertaken show that determination of rock strength parameters through P- and S-wave velocity measurements can be done reliably. Those parameters can be extrapolated to
a wider geographical area by rebound measurements. Refraction seismics can then be used to
determine depth of weathered rock and give a picture of vertical sound velocity distribution.

fields.title: Vej mellem Sisimiut og Kangerlussuaq - Baggrundsrapport for VVM-redegørelse
Analyse af recipienterne af spildevand i Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
In this report a survey has been done on the near shore environment around Sisimiut regarding ocean currents, nutrients, oxygen level, heavy metals and bacteria in the water phase and in the sediment. This has been done because of the fact that all wastewater is discharged directly into the ocean, without any preceding treatment. The wastewater is discharged from the shore face different places in the city; both to the fjord Ulkebugten and the more open sea west of the city. Thereby the purpose of this project is to estimate whether this form of wastewater discharge is a threat to the surrounding marine environment or to the people of Sisimiut.
It has been found that the water exchange of the area is very limited. Thereby the different pollutants have a greater potential negative effect of the region because they don’t spread and dilutes very easily. From the rest of the results it has been found, that there is an enhanced concentration of heavy metals in the waster phase and the sediments of the surrounding sea. The most problematic heavy metals have shown to be cadmium and copper. From the results it cannot with certainty be concluded whether eutrophication is a problem or not, even though there have been found enhanced concentrations of phosphor several places. Regarding the amount of bacteria in the water phase there is an indication of an enhanced amount some places. Especially the fecal coliform bacteria with resistance to antibiotics can be a threat to people’s health, if they get in contact with this kind of bacteria.
By the conclusions drawn in this rapport, it is recommended that all wastewater is treated before being discharged to the ocean, so that the level of bacteria, heavy metals, nutrients and other pollutants is reduced. At the same time it is important that the wastewater is discharged further away from the city to a place with greater water exchange. Further more it is recommended that Royal Greenland does the same – eventually they could find another way to handle the waste from the production.

fields.title: Vandressourcer på Itilleq
fields.abstract:
This report is a continuation of the report “Water supply in Greenland – Itilleq and Sisimiut –”,
which aims to find an additional or alternative solution to the existing water resources on Itilleq.
The purpose of the present report is to investigate if the well (brønd 3), which was identified in the
previous project, fulfils the conditions needed if it is to be a part of the water supply system on
Itilleq. Before this can happen an approval from the home rule of Greenland is demanded. In the
case that it is desired to make a final application for the approval of the well, this report is structured
so that it deals with the main questions in such an application. This is done so interested parties can
benefit most efficiently from the project.
A preliminary analysis of the existing water supply system and its production is made together with
an examination of the drinking water consumption on the island. From this it has been concluded
that there is an increasing water consumption demand and thereby a higher need of water resources.
In this connection is has become clear that the existing system is not able to fulfil the demand from
the consumers in some periods, whereby it has been acknowledge that an expansion of the system is
needed. Brønd 3 has been seen as a potential solution for this purpose, therefore an estimation of the
catchmentarea and a suggestion for a border zone around the well has been made.
Furthermore the technical condition of the well has been evaluated and there have been no greater
problems. In connection with this an estimation of the technical installation that will have to be
made has been given. This mainly consists of about 150 m water pipe and a shed to cover the well.
Additionally a bacteriological and chemical analysis of the water quality for the well has been
made. The results from this were exclusively positive, since they were all within the specific
threshold limits. I most incidents the water quality in brønd 3 was even better than the quality of the
existing drinking water system.
Finally analysis to expose the capacity of the well is made. The analyses are based on pumping data
and recovery tests. Additionally a water balance for the well is composed by use of local and
regional climate data. From the results of these analyses it can be concluded that the well supplies
sufficient quantities of water during the summer. However, there was not enough data available to
conclude whether the well capacity is adequate in wintertime.
An overall conclusion for the report is that nothing speaks directly against an approval of the well
for a drinking water purpose. But on the other hand this report can not be considered as conclusive
base for approval of the well, because of the missing data concerning the well capacity in the winter
period.

fields.abstract:

fields.title: Forundersøgelser på Akia, Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
Sisimiut is the second largest town in Greenland and is still experiencing a
continous population growth. As a concequence there is an increasing de-
mand for new areas for town expansion and it has been decided to assign an
area north of the town called Akia to this purpose. The aim of this project
is to evaluate whether the various plans for a part of the assigned area, A21
on Akia, can be realized.
The project includes preliminary studies including geophysical sounding and
profiling, drilling, geotechnical field and laboratory experiments. Furthermore
the geological structure of the area is treated.
It is concluded that the depth to the bedrock is limited, which means that
there will be no problems in constructing houses as long as they are founded
on piles driven to the bedrock or directly on the rock surface.
The soil is proven frost susceptible and of low strength. Furthermore perma-
frost related surface features are observed. As a consequence roads cannot be
placed in the valleys as planned and must therefore be placed onto the rock.
If placement in the valleys is not avoidable, the frostsusceptible materials
have to be replaced with sand or gravel.
Foundings independent of the permafrozen ground are believed to be the
only option in Sisimiut in the future.

fields.title: Vakuumrørssolfangere og sæsonvarmelagring under arktiske forhold
fields.abstract:
The energy supply of Greenland is mainly based on oil. Due to different circumstances such as the future resource scarcity as well as environmental considerations, this situation is considered unsustainable. The aim of this project is therefore to examine whether if solar heating, supplied by evacuated tubular solar collectors, and seasonal heat storage could be a realistic alternative, if based on energy concerns only. A model for calculating the performance of a solar collector has been modified to consider Greenlandic conditions. The model was sought verified by experi-mental measurements, which were carried out on evacuated tubes placed under different condi-tions in Sisimiut in Greenland.
Though with some reservations, the model has been verified. Calculations of the collector per-formance for a solar heating plant based on evacuated tubular solar collectors placed in Sisimiut showed that with almost full exploitation of the produced solar heat, it would be possible to cover 20- 30 % of the heat demand, which is covered by oil today. Further calculations showed that a higher coverage of the heat demand would decrease the possibility to exploit the pro-duced solar heat – and thereby the installed solar collector area – exponentially; this being a re-sult of the incoherent relationship between the solar availability and the heat demand. It is pos-sible to account for variations within a day or a week by using a buffer tank; though not for longer periods. Hence the possibility of storing the solar heat in the underground on seasonal basis has been explored.
The investigations showed that a “bore hole”-storage would be the best suited type of seasonal heat storage assuming a large amount of heat is stored. Based on literature studies, geological investigations and simulations of a bore hole storage using the program “Earth Energy Design-er”, EED, bore hole storages were assessed feasible with regard to energy concerns given the arctic conditions present in Sisimiut. A heat loss of around 50 % was found and considered to be reasonable.
Different scenarios for the energy supply system in Sisimiut were set up. In these a solar heating plant and a seasonal heat storage were integrated. In scenarios based on the current energy sup-ply system investigations using EED and the verified model show that a combination of solar heating and seasonal heat storage could replace the oil based heat production completely with a reasonable utilisation of the installed solar collectors.
Since it is a political aim in Greenland to replace the oil based energy supply system with water power in the future, a water power dominated scenario for the energy supply in Sisimiut 2050 was set up. Investigations showed that if an abundant water power supply is available, solar heat would probably not be considered. However, to ensure energy supply storage of energy is prob-ably a necessity. In this case seasonal heat storage could be a possibility, though other solutions seem more appropriate.

fields.title: TBT i området omkring Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
This report deals with the TBT pollution of the area around Sisimiut harbour and is based on fieldwork in Sisimiut, Greenland in the period from 23 July to 13 August 2003.
TBT is a broad-spectrum biocide mainly used as an antifouling agent in boat paint. The idea of antifouling paint is to prevent algae and small animals from settling on surfaces in contact with water. Fouling on ships deteriorates the manoeuvring capability and raises the water resistance, thereby increasing the fuel consumption.
TBT is probably one of the most toxic chemicals ever released to the aquatic environment. Unlike other antifouling agents, TBT will last for about 5 years, depending on the thickness of the TBT layer. Furthermore TBT is very effective even in small concentrations (>0,5 TBT pr. L) and as another advantage; it is released slowly at constant rate from the pained surface.
TBT is now found in many parts of the world and is becoming a global problem due to certain unfortunate properties: persistence, bioaccumulation and high toxicity. Today research is conducted in order to find alternatives to TBT, but it is difficult to find an antifouling agent as effective as TBT.
In the EU, the member states have made it their obligation to prohibit painting with TBT by the year 2003, resulting in a total elimination of TBT from 2008. These regulations on TBT have improved the aquatic environment in some areas, but TBT can still be found in large concentrations in many places, especially in areas with heavy sea traffic, e.g. close to harbours. Since TBT is still used for large vessels in many areas, and because TBT only degrades slowly in the natural environment, it is expected that TBT-polluted sediments will continue to be a problem for years to come.
Greenland and its inhabitants are particularly exposed to the effects of TBT due to their high preference for seafood, where TBT might be accumulated, combined with the risk of sea currents transporting TBT to the Arctic from other areas. Many Greenlanders enjoy raw seal liver where TBT has a tendency to accumulate.
The sediment in the industrial harbour in Sisimiut has previously been analysed for TBT. The investigation showed that the sediment is highly polluted from both TBT and heavy metals.
An important task for us was to see if the TBT pollution was limited to the industrial harbour, or if the whole area around Sisimiut was polluted. There is also a harbour for small leisure boats in Sisimiut and this harbour has not been analysed for TBT previously. It is conceivable that this harbour might also be contaminated with TBT as leisure boats often are treated with antifouling agents as well. Furthermore, not all ships coming to Sisimiut, use one of the two harbours. Many of large vessels, e.g. ferries, dock at the outer quay adjacent to Ulkebugten or at the Royal Greenland quay.
The areas around Sisimiut, especially Ulkebugten, was analysed for TBT in order to conclude whether the harbours are a source for TBT pollution or whether sea currents and large vessels would be likely to bring TBT into the area.
The fieldwork consisted of sample collection, lab work and stakeholder meetings. Sample collection in Ulkebugten as well as in the area around the harbour was done using special equipment (in Danish en haps) from a fishing boat, while the samples taken in the two harbours were taken with an other form of special equipment (in Danish en grab) from a small boat.
By considering organic content and the size of the grains in a sample it is possible to evaluate whether it is likely that TBT would bind to the sediment in that particular area. TBT has a tendency to bind to organic matter as well as silt and clay.
The organic content of the samples from Ulkebugten was measured to be around 7 % in the inner most part of the bay at the river mouth and about 4 % further out towards the sea. The dominant
grain size in the bay was found to be silt (0,002 - 0,063 mm). This means that TBT easily would be able to bind to the sediment in this area. Nevertheless, the measurements of TBT in Ulkebugten showed that TBT could not be found in spite of the good binding conditions.
In the leisure boat harbour the TBT concentration was measured at 2,7 μg Sn pr. kg dry weight. This is not a lot compared with many Danish leisure boat harbours, but it is still severe, since it can cause crucial effects on the environment. The industrial harbour was also found to be contaminated with TBT, but in much higher doses. In the innermost part of the harbour, near the shipyard, we found concentrations at 652 μg Sn pr. kg dry weight, which is high compared to Danish harbours. The value far exceeds the ecotoxicological values (EC50-values). This means that life in the industrial harbour must be limited because of TBT. In the outer part of the harbour the TBT concentration was “only” 13,4 μg Sn pr. kg dry weight, which is a huge difference from the 652 μg Sn pr. kg in the inner part. These numbers are based on six samples from the harbour pooled in groups of three. This does not give us the possibility of analysing the statistical uncertainty of the measurements.
The good news is that the sediment from the harbour does not seem to contaminate large parts of the area. Only in the samples H10 and H11 from just outside the harbour we found TBT. The reason why, these two samples are contaminated and not the others, probably, either that these two samples were taken relatively close to the industrial harbour or because they had a large content of organic matter in the form of waste from the Royal Greenland factory or both. If the waste from Royal Greenland contains TBT (because the shrimps and crabs were exposed to TBT when they lived), it is of outmost importance to investigate whether TBT is in the shells from shrimps and crabs or if it is in the meat we eat. Further investigations are necessary to clarify this issue.
This constitutes a problem, as most harbours must be cleaned regularly in order to avoid total sedimentation of the harbour. Therefore, large amounts of sludge must be removed and either dumped or treated. Previously, the sediment from Sisimiut industrial harbour was dumped, but this is not a sustainable solution, since the pollution will be spread in the environment with time.
In the light of the high TBT concentration in the inner part of the harbour we strongly advice not to dump the sediment since this action would have serious damaging effects for the environment. Preferably the sediments should be treated and cleaned, but an efficient method is not yet found.
In 2002, an experiment was conducted concerning the possible treatment of TBT-polluted sludge from Sisimiut harbour. The experiment entailed construction of four boxes that were filled with sand and a thin layer of sediment from the harbour. The four boxes were kept under different conditions in order to evaluate witch conditions influence degradation of TBT. It is known that UV-light from the sun, certain microorganisms and the presence of oxygen has some influence on the degradation process. In connection with this, the special arctic climate constitutes a big challenge, since the activity level of microorganisms degrading TBT is lower in cold environments.
To continue the work done in 2002, we took samples from the boxes in order to investigate whether TBT had been degraded in the year that passed. In particular we wanted to find out if the degradation of TBT was dependent on the depth within the sediment layer. The TBT concentration turned out to be highest in the top layer and lower in the bottom. This indicates that TBT has been degraded in the bottom of the sediments, perhaps because it is warmer in the lowest layers. This is an advantage for the microorganisms that degrade TBT. The UV-light from the sun does not seem to influence the degradation very much.
The experiment with the boxes did not give a clear result. The experiment was too uncertain and further investigations are necessary before the method is rejected. Nevertheless we estimate that this method is slow and troublesome under arctic conditions.

fields.title: Klassifikation ved brug af MODIS-billeder
fields.abstract:
Dette projekt omhandler klassifikation og
arealbestemmelse af smeltevandssøer på
indlandsisen på Grønlands vestkyst ved brug af MODIS-satellitbilleder fra år 2000 –
2002. Der er givet en overordnet beskrivelse af, hvordan MODIS-instrumentet fungerer,
hvilke dataprodukter der er til rådighed, samt
hvad disse produkter indeholder. Herudover
en beskrivelse af teorien bag transformation og opretning af billeder samt de benyttede
klassifikationsmetoder.
Hvis muligt skulle der findes en udvikling af søernes areal over hvert år. Der er blevet
afprøvet følgende klassifikationsmetoder for at opfylde dette formål:
•
Threshold
•
Superviseret klassifikation
o
Minimum Distance
o
Maximum Likelihood
o
Bayes Decision Rule
•
Usuperviseret klassifikation
o
ISODATA
•
Teksturfilter
o
Efterfulgt af et morfologisk closingfilter
o
Usuperviseret klassifikation m. et teksturlag
•
Transformationer af data
o
Kvadratroden
o
Logaritmen
o
NDVI
•
Principal Component Analyse (PCA)
Ingen af nævnte metoder har givet en arealbestemmelse der har været præcis nok til, at en
udvikling over året har kunne følges, men alligevel er PCA blevet benyttet til at
arealbestemme søerne, da det var den metode, som gav de bedste resultater. Det har
derfor været nødvendigt at bestemme en middelværdi over hvert år, da resultaterne har
været svingende. Temperaturen i området forklarer ikke stigningen i 2001.
Det er blevet undersøgt om en klassifi
kation af strækningen mellem Sisimiut og
Kangerlussuaq har været mulig ved brug af MODIS-billeder, hvilket ikke har været
tilfældet, pga. billedernes grove opløsning.
Det vurderes, at MODIS-billeder kan bruges til at estimere arealet over året, men der er
usikkerheder ved brug at PCA, og det tilrådes at finde andre og bedre metoder, hvis
muligt.

fields.abstract:

fields.title: Tungmetaller i det marine miljø omkring Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
In this report heavy metals in water and sediment samples from around Sisimiut have
been examined. The wastewater from the village is discharged directly into the sea
without any preceding treatment. The obj
ective of this report is to estimate whether
the wastewater discharge contains heavy metals and thus constitutes a threat to the
marine environment or to the people of Sisimiut. The sediment samples have been
collected in the bay of Ulkebugten and along th
e coastline all the way to the
”chocolate” factory.
Analyses of the water and the sediment samples have indicated an increased
concentration of the heavy metals cadmium and copper. This means that the two
heavy metals in question might have an ecotoxicolo
gical effect on the environment.
Furthermore, b
ased on the results it can be concluded that the water exchange of the
bay of Ulkebugten is rather limited. Thus, the heavy metals are not dispersed but
remain where they are discharged.
Based on t
he results
i
t can be concluded that heavy
metals
pollute
the marine envir
onment around Sisimiut
.
Based on the above it can be concluded that the wastewater must be treated before
being discharged into the sea. This is also applicable to the waste discharged from the
Royal Greenland plant. Furthermore, it is recommended that the wastewater be
discharged further out to sea in order that a stronger current could carry it away from
the village. It is recommended that something is done about the situation in the bay
Ulkebu
gten as the water exchange in the bay is limited.
However, this might not be enough to solve the problem, as arctic areas such as
Greenland are subjected to heavy metals from other countries due to the water and
wind conditions.

fields.title: Undersøgelse af lerforekomster ved Ameragdla, Qugssuk, Ilulialik og Kangerlussuaq
fields.abstract:
The Ameragdla, Qugssuk and Ilulialik areas in the Nuuk region of
Greenland have been investigated with the intention of locating raised
clay deposits suitable for tile production.
Clay from a previously investigated deposit, Fossilsletten at Kanger-
lussuaq, was found to have a fine composition except for a critical
amount of chloride salts due to the aride climate of the region. This
clay deposit was formed by glaciofluvial deposition of sediments ero-
ded from the archaean block by the inland ice. As a result of glacial
rebound, isostatic uplift has raised parts of the sediments above pre-
sent sea level. Using geological maps, deposits formed under similar
conditions were sought in the humid Nuuk area. At Ameragdla and
Qugssuk large raised clay deposits were found at or in close proximity
of the selected areas. Access to these sites by boat was difficult because
of large banks of clayey mud (2-20 km) blocking the entrance to the
inner fjords even at high tide. At Ilulialik access was not possible,
however the presence of huge mud banks still suggest the existence
of raised clay deposits. On basis of particle size distributions all clay
samples were categorized as fat or weakly silty. The clay minerals con-
tents were below 1 wt%, the clay consisting primarily of parent rock
minerals such as placioclase, quartz and orthoclase. This is believed to
be the cause of slow weathering in the cold climate. The chloride con-
tents were 0.05
±
0.02 wt% and 0.002
±
0.002 wt% for the Ameragdla
and Qugssuk clays, respectively, which is well below the critical limit.
Test-burnings of the Ameragdla clay produced tile of good quality and
nice dark red colour, while the Qugssuk tile had poor color and quickly
formed salt efflorences. The plasticity of the Qugssuk clay is too low
for industrial moulding in its pure form, hence the Ameragdla clay
is considered to be the more suitable for industrial tile production.
Additionally, new findings suggests the chloride content to be of less
importance than previously believed, therefore we advocate a reeva-
luation on the quality of the Kangerlussuaq-clay.

fields.title: Rensning af aske fra forbrændingsanlæg i Sisimiut, Grønland
fields.abstract: The aim of this report is to give an insight about how the waste situation in Greenland is, compared to that of Denmark, including considerations one might take into account regarding the environmental problems. Recently Greenland started to use municipal solid waste incinerators as a part of their new waste management strategies, however new problems have occurred regarding what to do with the remaining ash fraction. This ash is often enriched with a high content of heavy metals, and since depositing of the ash, is not seen as a desirable solution politically, other alternative methods have to be considered to neutralize this ash. The method we have selected and worked with, in order to find a solution to this problem, is that of electrodialytic removal of heavy metals from fly ashes. We have chosen to focus on Cd and Pb, since these are among the most toxic elements found in the ash. We found that Pb shown to be the most difficult element to remove. Our experiments have shown that already after one week significant amount of Cd has been removed (approximately 91 %), and only 18 % Pb was removed. We repeated the experiment once more and this time we let it go on for 3 weeks and this also gave good results; 96 % of the Cd and 27 % of the Pb was removed. A large part of the ash however deteriorated during the experiments, thus giving a higher end concentration of the heavy metal in the end ash fraction. The remaining part of the heavy metal will also be the one most heavily bounded to the remaining ash. With a complete removal of the desorption agent further leaching might be avoided.

fields.title: Undersøgelse af olieforurenet grund i Sisimiut, samt rensning af jorden ved kompostering
fields.abstract: The present report is about soil pollution in the centre of Sisimiut in Greenland. Primarily, the spatial distribution of the pollution is investigated. A summery of results from Carl Bro A/S shows that the soil is highly polluted with hydrocarbons; especially from gasoline and fuel oil. PID-measurements performed during july-august 2002 shows that the soil is still polluted with hydrocarbons but not in the same amount. The theory of composting indicates that it is possible to compost in an arctic environment. Batch experiments with different conditions is set up, variables are: Nutrients, crab-shells, drain/no-drain and temperature. The current results show a reduction in the concentration of hydrocarbons.

fields.title: Anvendelse af Landsat 7 billeder til glaciologiske undersøgelser i Sisimiut Kommune, Grønland
Vandkvalitet i Erikfjordområdet
Geomorfologisk landskabsanalyse ved 2. fjorden
fields.abstract:
Formålet med projektet er at lokalisere og klassificere en eventuel randmoræne, der 
tidligere med ekkolod, er blevet observeret i 2. fjorden. Ekkoloddet viste en meget 
markant tærskel tværs over fjorden. Projektet tager udgangspunkt i marinseismiske 
data, der så sammenholdes med data indsamlet på land. De marinseismiske data vil 
forhåbentlig give en oversigt over de undersøiske sedimentære forhold i fjorden. De 
på land indsamlede data skal give et mere detaljeret overblik af aflejringsformen og 
kornstørrelsesfordelingen. Disse to datasæt skal samlet give en indikation af den 
overordnede landskabsudvikling i området. 
Endvidere ønskes det at give et overblik over hvilke processer der er dominerende i 
forhold til den morfologiske udvikling af området. Denne del af opgaven tager 
udgangspunkt i de teoretiske forhold der kan forklare den observerede sedimentologi. 
Disse processer forventes at være af glacial, fluvial, marin og periglacial karakter og 
derfor vil hovedvægten af den teoretiske og analytiske del være koncentreret omkring 
netop disse procestyper.

fields.title: Forurening i Arktis - Dye 1
Mikroorganismer i havvandet omkring Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
The aim of the report is to examine the environment of the ocean, by examined the microbiology in 
the ocean surrounding Sisimiut. 
Water samples have been taken in the summer of 2002. 
There is employed disc spreading for increased reproduction of microorganisms from selected 
Colonies. Threes colonies have been cleaned out and examinad in the microscope. 
The DNA and the RNA of the colonies have been cleaned out. 
There has been selected two samples for species determination by PCR reproduction. The disc 
spreading resulted in findings of a large number of microorganisms in the ocean area near the two 
outflows of the town. These microorganisms can constitute a health risk and calls for further 
investigation in order to determine the hazard for the inhabitants of the area. 
Appearantly there is a greater amount of microorganisms in the ocean near Sisimiut. This is due 
caused by contamination of nutrients and microorganisms.

fields.title: Analyse af eksistens af - samt tilgængelighed til grønlandsrelaterede data
fields.abstract:
Present report assesses the accessibility of existing data related to Greenland and 
proposes a series of actions in order to improve the accessibility. The assessments are 
based on a number of interviews and studies of literature regarding organisations 
working with data related to Greenland. 
It is examined if there is a demand for the possibility of being able to search for data 
using a geographical key and whether this need is satisfied by existing solutions. 
The technical aspects concerning the establishment of a central database regarding 
metadata about data related to Greenland is discussed followed by an evaluation of 
the realistic feasibilities of the establishment of such a system. 
A general conclusion is that the accessibility of existing data related to Greenland is 
disproportionately poor and that no change for the better has occurred despite the 
increasing attention to the problem during recent years. The existing organisational 
culture substantially counteracts initiatives to improve accessibility. 
Finally a number of recommendations are listed in order to improve the accessibility 
of data. The proposed solutions seek to allow improvements on accessibility both on 
short- and far sight.

fields.title: Geoidehøjden i Sisimiut en analyse af sammenhængen mellem geoidemodeller og middelvandstand
fields.abstract:
This report contains a valuation of the quality of different coordinatlists 
for the fixed points in Sisimiut, Greenland along with an analysis of the 
connection between different geoidmodels and mean sea level. Generally 
it can be concluded that the coordinatlists are of vary quality. 
Additionally the offset between the geoidmodels Geoide96 and 
Geoide2000 and the mean sea level in Sisimiut is found.

fields.title: Forsøg med tungmetaller og TBT i havnesediment i Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
During a 3-weeks field study in Greenland, a field experiment was conducted with the 
purpose of determining whether it is possible to degrade Tributyltin (TBT). TBT is used 
in antifouling paints, but it can cause imposex, so that female marine snails start to 
develop masculine features. TBT has a long degradation time – especially under 
anaerobic conditions. 
In the light of a successful degradation of TBT in an experiment which willows are used 
to take up some contaminants like heavy metals in their roots in harbour sediments in 
Kalvehave Harbour (Arildskov & Villumsen, 2002) – but where willows did not take up 
TBT – it was decided to carry out a similar project in Greenland – however without 
willows. Even though the willows didn’t have a direct effect by uptake of TBT, the trees 
can create more favourable conditons for microorganisms. It is assumed that degradation 
of TBT can be done by photolysis and microbiel degradation. 
In practise, the experiment was carried out by building 4 boxes for the purpose. A sand 
layer of approximately 20-30 cm in order to filtrate the water from the harbour sludge. 
This water is then reused when distributing the slugde in an even and homogeneous layer 
in the boxes on top of the sand. The filtrating water does, however, contain larger 
concentrations of heavy metals than water from the harbour fra Sisimiut Harbour. This 
can be due to an increased turbidity in the filtrating water from the boxes, so that metals 
can be found in increasing concentrations as they tend to sorb to particles to a larger 
extent. Another possibility is that the geotextile in the bottom and sides of the boxes is 
not entirely closed to fine-grained particles or if tiny external contaminations on the 
boxes have contaminated the water samples. The concentrations of metals in these water 
samples are, however, not so ecotoxilogically damaging as the concentrations in the 
sediments. 
Regarding the primary purpose of this assignment – i.e. content and degradation of TBT 
in harbour sediments – this has not been accomplished at the date of handing in the 
report, because of a busy schedule at the National Environmental Research Institute of 
Denmark (NERI) has not yet analyzed the 13 sediment samples for TBT. 
Instead a qualitative evaluation is performed on e.g. the ratio between TBT and Total 
butyltin in the harbour of Sisimiut compared to the Kalvehave Harbour in Denmark. The 
greater ratio in Sisimiut indicates a possible slower degradation of TBT in the Greenland 
harbour sediment as a result of lower temperatures. This could suggest that the 
degradation half-time is prolonged compared to Danish conditions. Another possible 
explanation the higher TBT-concentration compared to its degradation products could be 
that in Denmark, TBT use has been banned for boats shorter than 25 meters since 1991. 
The TBT-results are therefore anticipated, because this method, if it works in Greenland, 
will be a relatively cheap and a low-technology tool to solve universal pollution 
problems. The method has no effect on concentration of heavy metals in the sediments, 
which are often present in high concentrations in harbour sludge. The method can, however, be combined with plantation of willows that can take up heavy metals. The 
ashes from the burned trees can then be purified by electrodialysis, by which the metals 
can removed from the sediment, and fore instance reused.

fields.title: Vandforsyning i Grønland - Itilleq og Sisimiut -
fields.abstract:
In the summer of 2002 field work was carried out on the island of Itilleq. The
purpose of this field work was to locate an alternate waterressource for watersupply,
as the currently used well (Well 1) is unable to supply sufficient amounts
of water in the wintertime. This is due to the formation of a natural threshold
in the earth (a so-called bedrock-threshold) at a critical point in the catchment
area of the well.
Prior to arrival at the fieldsite an older well (Well 3) was identified with
the aid of aerial photos as having a significantly larger catchment area. Upon
arrival geophysical investigations (VLF and geoelectrical surveying) were therefore
concentrated within this catchment area. By means of these investigations
the depth to the bedrock has been determined to be approximately 5 metres in
the lower part of the catchment area, while it decreases to a little less than 1
metre in the upper part of catchment area.
It has not been possible to determine whether a bedrock-threshold is present
in the catchment area of Well 3. However, by comparing the acquired geophysical
data for catchment 1 and 3 it has been possible to decide that a bedrockthreshold
is not likely to occur in catchment 3, as the depth to the bedrockthreshold
in catchment 1 is only 2.5 metres.
In conducted pumping tests on Well 3 it was possible to maintain a yield
capacity of 1 l
s for approximately 90 minutes at a time. This corresponds to a
yield of 5.4 m3.
Furthermore water samples were taken from the water in Well 3, from which
it can be concluded that the water from the well is of good quality. This means
that the concentrations of the measured compounds calcium, magnesium, iron,
manganese, sodium, potassium, bromide, fluoride, chloride, sulphate, phosphate,
nitrate and nitrite all lie below international limit values.
It can hereby be concluded that Well 3 provides a good alternative to the
present watersupply. Further investigations should, however, be carried out to
determine the actual yield (capacity) of the well and to ascertain whether
bedrock-thresholds occur within its catchment. Bacteriological examinations of
the water should also be carried out.
Another aspect of this project concerned with the geological mapping of the
iv
v
sediments underneath Waterlake 5 in Sisimiut and their thicknesses. Through
seismic surveying on the lake-surface and following interpretation it can be established
that the minimum-thickness of the sedimentlayers under the lake is
4 metres. However, it has been estimated that the thicknesses in some parts of
the lake reach 15 metres. This, however has not been verified.
Furthermore water-samples have been taken in Waterlake 5, Waterlake 3,
the ’scout-lake’ and in the pipelines of the water supply system. These samples
confirm that the presently used drinking water from Waterlake 5 is of good
quality. A general contamination of the ’scout-lake’ has occured.
It is suggested that test drillings are carried out in the sedimentlayers under
the waterlake to obtain an idea of what types of sediments are found there and
to learn their water storage capacity (porosity, water content and so on). This
can be combined with test pumpings in the sediment to establish whether it is
possible to pump from here (to determine possible yield capacity).

fields.title: Ler fra Kangerlussuaq til teglsten
fields.abstract:
The main purpose of this project is to investigate the size of deposits of clay in 
Kangerlussuaq on the West coast of Greenland and the possibilities for burning the clay 
in order to produce tiles. This also includes an examination of the production- and 
marketing conditions. 
To form an idea of the composition of the deposits the area is described in proportion to 
its regional- and local geology. The result is that the composition of the minerals in the 
deposits is a product of erosion of the Archaean Block which consists of quartzose and 
feldsparic gneisses and the Nagssugtoqidian Mobile Belt which mostly consists of gneiss 
in amphibolite facies. The transformations or the breakdown of the minerals primarily 
occurs in the process of mechanical weathering. Due to the arid climate and the relatively 
low average temperature in the area the chemical weathering slows down to a minimum. 
This means that the chemical weathering is negligible. The deposition of sediments 
occurring today and which has occurred earlier in the area is characterized by the forming 
of a delta at the location where the glacial stream and the saline water from the fiord meet 
each other. The saline water causes the fine minerals to flocculate. 
The surveying of the plain is done using geophysical and ordinary surface measurements. 
The geophysical measurements are only carried out with the seismic measurement 
method in form of refraction and reflection seismic explorations. The data found by the 
refraction method were treated by Jens Nykjær Larsen while the data found by the 
reflection method were treated and interpreted by the rest of the group. The results show 
that there is a considerable agreement between the interpretation of the refraction and the 
reflection seismic sections. The results make it possible to recognize a refractor which 
submerges from the depth of 20 m to the depth of 130 m below the surface in a distance 
of 250 m from the mountain. The first sign of a reflector is found at a distance of 
approximately 250 m from the mountain. It has been attempted to convert the interpreted 
results into depths which has resulted in reflector depths between 105 m to 300 m below 
the surface. The reflector slopes southwards with an estimated average inclination 
between 28 and 37 degrees. Furthermore it is possible to recognize a reflector in an 
estimated depth between 105 m and 150 m. This reflector indicates that a structure in the 
deposit may be possible to recognize.

fields.title: Udviklingsmuligheder i Sisimiut - Set i et teknologiperspektiv
fields.abstract:
In this project we seek to analyze the present development situation in Sisimiut and the impacts a construction of a stretch of road between Sisimiut and Kangerlussuaq may have on various areas of development, such as the systems of transportation, the trades and industries, tourism, and politics. 

By applying the theory of The Social Construction of Technology the key actors are identified and analyzed in the context in which they appear and the social and technical relations, which they represent. 

It is found that the stretch of road may have a positive influence on the future situation and development of the areas, attracting new work forces and possibly new arrivals of companies. Though, it is noted that it may bring about changes to the existing ways of transportation and that the costs exceed the financial limits of the local municipality. Furthermore, it is pointed out that the layout of the stretch of road needs to be clear of the existing dog sledge tracks, fishing and hunting grounds. Also, the need of informing and communicating with the public in the project process plays an important role.

Geologi og Tungmetal i Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
From introduction:
Naturligt indhold af tungmetalle
r på verdensplan er sjældent
et problem, fordi naturen
gennem millioner af år har tilpasset sig
disse små mængder. I Grønland derimod er
tungmetaller et miljøproblem, der til stadig
hed har været tilstede op gennem historien.
Det kan blandt andet ses ved målinger på de
godt 5000 år gamle mumier fra Qilakitsoq,
der nu er udstillet på Grønlands Nati
onalmuseum /www.jp.dk, 2001/. Forklaringen på
dette fænomen skal findes i nedbrydnings pr
ocesserne under arktiske forhold samt de
store mængder tungmetal, som er naturligt
forekommende i Grønland /Kalaallit Nunaat,
1999/. Problemet bliver ikke mindre, når der
bliver taget højde fo
r de enorme mængder
af tungmetaller, der udledes fra den industr
ielle verden i dag, hv
ilket har gjort, at
belastningen på miljøet for stort.
Opgaven tager udgangspunkt i eksamensprojektet
Disposal of Residual Products in
Sisimiut
af Martha Louise Rødbro og Sune
Yding (DTU, 2000), som omhandler
etableringen af et depot i Depot Valley til
deponering af tungmetalholdigt farligt affald.
(se Kort 3) Her tænkes på restprodu
kterne (slagger og flyveaske) fra
affaldsforbrændingen.
I rapporten vil der bliv
e bearbejdet en række afsnit,
som omhandler geologi i Grønland,
en geologisk og til dels geokemisk undersøgels
e af feltområdet nedstrøms Depot Valley
samt en kort vurdering af feltområdet i tilfæl
de af udslip fra depotet. Det skal pointeres
at Depot Valley kun er det, af Sune og L
ouise, opmålte område. De nedenfor liggende
benævnes fremover plateau 1, -2 og -3.
Tidligere tiders affaldshåndter
ing gik ud på at dumpe alt a
ffald i et dalstrøg. I andre
tilfælde har befolkningen dumpet de
res affald lige uden for hoveddøren.
Konsekvenserne af denne type affaldshåndt
ering ses tydeligt i Si
simiut, og specielt på
Dumpen, som indeholder alle typer affald
fra et samfund af denne størrelse.
Dette har skabt et seriøst miljømæssigt probl
em, ikke kun fordi affaldet ikke nedbrydes
så hurtigt under arktiske fo
rhold, men også fordi produkterne,
som er blevet dumpet, er
mere miljøskadelige. I det sidste århundrede og ikke mindst de sidste 40 år er det gået
stærkt med forureningen. Dette skyldes, at
mange nye produkter er
blevet introduceret i
det grønlandske samfund, hvorved den gamle tradition med fuld udnyttelse af 
ressourcerne ikke længere finder sted. Ma
nge af disse nye pr
odukter indeholder
samtidigt miljøfremmede stoffer, hvilket
giver problemer med den traditionelle
grønlandske affaldshåndtering. 
Der genereres i dag store mængder tungmetal fra forbrændingsanlæg rundt om i
Grønland. Det er oplagt at an
alysere Sisimiuts forbrændings
anlægs restprodukter, da det
er Grønlands nyeste, og det har været praktis
k muligt at besøge selve anlægget. Som en
konsekvens af forbrændingsanlægget er a
ffaldsmængden (men ikke mængden af
tungmetaller) i Sisimiut reduceret med en
faktor ti. Både slagge og flyveaske fra
affaldsforbrændingen indeholder en volds
om koncentration af tungmetaller.

fields.abstract:
Wastewater in Greenland is for the most part released into  the aquatic environment without 
treatment. This can have unwanted effects on the aquatic life especially problematic around the 
lager cities. In this project the focus is therefore on the consequences  of releasing untreated 
wastewater to the aquatic life. The organisms that  are used in the experiments are mud scrimp and 
brown algae. 
 
The chemical indicators measured i.e. nutrients and heavy metals show a local contamination 
source at the wastewater outlet be low the hospital. This corresponds well with the mortality of the 
mud scrimp which is also largest near the hospital. The high mortality can be explained by high 
amount of organic material which causes an anaer obic environment that the  scrimp cannot live in. 
The toxicity test with brown algae show Royal Greenland and the dump having the biggest 
inhibition on the growth parameters (length, weight and area). This is likely to be caused by the 
high concentrations heavy  metals observed here. 
 
In the future transplanting tests with algae in the environment should be considered. This would 
give a more realistic picture of the environmental effect on the organisms. Whereas the current tests 
only show effects of a stationary and momentary environment, the organisms  would be subjected to 
the natural and varying conditi ons in a transplanting test. 
Also the use of sediment dwelling plants like eel grass instead of mud scrimp for sediment surveys 
is suggested. The reason being that more parameters can be measured, parallel to the test conducted 
with brown algae, which may help to ensure a greater precision in the testing.

fields.title: Remediation of oil-contaminated soil in Arctic Climate
fields.abstract:
Human activities in Arctic regions relay on oil and oil-products for transportation and heating. This can lead to oil spills which can have devastating impacts on humans and the environment due to toxic compounds in the oil. Oil spills in the Arctic is a particular problem because the natural remediation processes is lowered compared to spills in temperate climate. The limiting factors regarding the biodegradation of oil-contaminated soils in the Arctic is the soil pH, the oxygen availability, the soil water content, the temperature and the soil nutrient content.
In this study an ex-sito remediation method is used to compare how efficiently the removal of oil-compound is by applying nutrients and heat individually and together to a light oil-contaminated soil in the Greenlandic town Sisimiut. A facility was built near the local waste incineration plant so the surplus heat from the plant can be used for heating the contaminated soil up to 40 oC. The nutrient supply originated from fertilized sphagnum.
Before the soil were placed in the facility it was run through a 1 cm grid and homogenized, no significant evaporation of light oil-compounds was detected during these steps, probably because the oil already was weathered before the procedures. The possible origin of the oil spill was expected to derive from an AGO gas oil but by comparing biomarkers with n-alkanes and by making a weathering check the AGO gas oil was found not to be the source for the oil spill.
In the heated setups an addition of 5 to 10 oC heat was enough to see significant higher oil removal compared to unheated soil. The soil where sphagnum had been added, elevated amounts of nitrogen was indicated, but in general there was a high heterogeneity and uncertainty regarding the nitrogen results. The phosphors concentration was more or less the same for all the setups.
42 days after the soil was placed in the remediation facility a visible reduction in light and middle sized oil-compounds was seen for all the setups, also in a control setup. 168 days after the startup day the reduction rate was not as high as from day 1 to 42, but further reduction was seen in some setups. Reasons for the lowering of the reduction rate could be low oil concentrations, low temperatures and/or too high water content in the soil. Biomarkers revealed biodegradation to be a significant removal process for the n-alkanes.
In the soil where both nutrients and heat was applied close to total removal of the light and middle sized hydrocarbons and the hydrocarbon isoprenoids pristane and phytane, used as biomarkers, was seen after 42 days,.
