Permafrost foundations in towns and settlements placed in areas without continuous permafrost are too risky. Temperatures are increasing and may continue to do so in the future.
It would be advantageous for urban life to be able to expand the cities without having to take areas with permafrost into account. However, at this time even foundations using correct methods do not guarantee the lifetime of the building, partly because the permafrost is already in the process of withdrawal, and partly because further temperature increases is to be expected with a certain probability.

fields.title: Geophysical surveys at Thule Air Base, Vehicle Maintenance
Processering og visualisering af lidar data
Geotechnical properties of glaciomarine sediments for harbour construction in from Kangerlusuaq fjord
fields.abstract:
The increase of city population, in the Arctic regions, is followed by a demand for increase in infrastructure. The increase, not only challenges road constructions, but also transportation of goods by ship and thereby harbour facilities. Additionally, the increase in tourism by cruise ship also demands for specific facilities.

Most of the cities on the Greenlandic west cost are able to accommodate the present and future requirements, by upgrading and expansion of existing harbour facilities. These cities are however located in areas where sedimentation is limited and bedrock conditions are favourable. Kangerlussuaq is, on the other hand, located in the bottom of a 175km long fjord with heavy sedimentation from the Greenlandic ice cap located only 40 to 50km from the city. Favourable bedrock and necessary water depth conditions are likewise not found near the existing city and construction of new harbour facilities on soft sediments may therefore be required. Knowledge of the soft sediments geotechnical properties are therefore of great importance.

A series of classification and advanced laboratory tests on sample/sediment material, collected from Brennan and Hancock point in Kangerlussuaq fjord, have been conducted in order to determine relevant soil properties. The geological model states that the sediment should be deposited by a flocculation process and consists of fine grained material smaller than 63um. Classification results, however show that in some locations the sediment contains gravel material, which is believed to originated from a drop till mechanism. The believed mechanism is denoted as sea ice drop till, where rock material are accumulated onshore in the winter time and later transported offshore when floes moves outward in the fjord, during the beginning of summer.

Despite the presence of coarse grained material the collected sample material is still classified as clay. Analysis of the grain size distribution has revealed clay contents between 45 and 70% dependent on the sample location. Additionally, the material contains approximately 15% very fine clay (< 0.2um) and is missing the coarse silt fraction. Hence, the sediment is denoted as gab-graded. In one sample a large amount of shell fragments have been found in the classification sequence, along with stones larger than 32mm. From the plasticity index the sediment is centred around the casagrande A-line and in the transition between high and medium plastic material. 

Based on the deposit type the sediment is expected to be normal consolidated, sensitive, and with low shear strength. Laboratory tests have illustrated, that the sample material on average attain a preconsolidation stress of: \sigma'_pc = \sigma'_0 + 15kPa. Fall-cone tests have shown, in-situ undrained shear strength in the range from 4 to 15kPa and remoulded strengths under 1kPa. Hence, mechanical disturbance of the material rapidly reduces the shear strength.
The advanced laboratory matrix includes, Direct Shear, Direct Simple Shear and Triaxial testing. Dependent on the test procedure ratios of c_u/\sigma_n ranges from 0.240 to 0.334, which illustrates that the sediment only possesses low shear strength even at high normal stresses.

Based on the entire test matrix, foundation of a future harbour structure on the soft sediment is not recommended. Loads from both the harbour itself and the application, should therefore be transferred to the bedrock. At present day knowledge of the bathymetry, sediment magnitude ect. are insufficient and a detailed harbour design can not be conducted until an extensive investigation of the mentioned factors are completed.

fields.title: Optimization of Zonge test setup
fields.abstract:
Denne rapport indeholder resultater fra et projekt foretager mellem september 2010 og februar 2011. Projektet har haft til formål at undersøge og optimere forskellige forsøgsopstillinger til CR-respons. Da der måles på meget små faseforskelle i mrad ved frekvenser mellem 1 og 9216Hz har påvirkninger fra de benyttede instrumenter en indflydelse på resultater. En optimal opstilling med så små påvirkninger fra instrumenter som muligt er derfor ønskelig.

Det har dog ikke været muligt at finde en opstilling som med tilstrækkelig præcision kan levere måleresultater svarede til en modellering. Ved frekvenser over 500Hz kan opstillingerne ikke længere levere tilstrækkelig præcise målinger, da instrumenter påvirker opstillingen i for høj grad. Ligeledes er gennem projektet opstået problemstillinger angående indre instrumenters virkemåde. Herunder er problemer som kan ses af resultater, men flere er ikke identificeret og bygger udelukkende på mistanke.

Projektet er resulteret i et antal afsluttende anbefalinger til efterfølgende undersøgelser.

fields.title: Geotekniske egenskaber af permafrost fra Ilulissat
fields.abstract:
It has been stated as a fact that the global temperature is rising. In different parts of the world, this leads to different new challenges, and on Greenland, the challenge is the thawing of the permafrost. The rising amount of water in the soil, changes the properties of the soil, and the changes will be easier to overcome if they are researched and described in advance.

The aim of this project is to test a numerical method for describing the temperature-dependency, the water content and the parameters of the soil. The numerical method takes into account the effect of latent heat, which is relevant for temperatures below the freezing point, when calculating the parameters investigated. The measurements of water content from an earlier study, are also used to test the numerical method, and the results are compared.

Furthermore, it is investigated how rising temperatures influences the resistivity and seismic velocity of a material, and classification-tests are performed.

Samples collected in Ilulissat in August 2013 were used for this project. Data describing water content and classification results from a previous study collected in Ilulissat 2011, was used as comparison.

It is shown in the project that there is a difference between using the numerical- and the analytical method. In the project, it is shown that the analytical method gave to high values for the heat capacity ??. The numerical method, is used for finding values for the thermal conductivity ?? and the heat capacity ??. The results also showed that there are small differences between the sampels collected in 2011 and 2013, when it comes to the watercontent, condition of parameters and classification-results.

It is also shown that rising temperatures results in lower resistivity and lower seismic velocity of the material.

fields.title: Korrelation af forundersøgelsesmetoderne ERT og CPTU
fields.abstract:
The purpose of this report is to describe how different ground investigation methods can be correlated to improve the combined results from each method. This report focuses on using cone penetration tests (CPT) to improve a profile created with electrical resistivity tomography (ERT).

Cone penetration test is a method for ground investigation used worldwide. This method collects data by pushing a cylindrical steel cone into the ground at a fixed speed. During this process, the cone resistance and sleeve friction are measured continuously. CPTU is an extended method that also includes measurements of the pore pressure in the soil. The CPT method does not enable the interpretation of materials but that of material behavior types. Sand behavior types can normally be identified by measuring a large tip resistance as well as a high sleeve friction and a hydrostatic pore pressure. Materials behaving as clay can be identified by measuring a low tip resistance, a low sleeve friction and a pore pressure above the hydrostatic pressure. Organic soil behavior types are normally characterized by a low tip resistance as well as a high sleeve friction. OCR soils tend to have a higher tip resistance than normal consolidated soils.

ERT combines profiling and sounding, so that a 2D data outline along the profile is obtained. The method measures the resistivity in the ground by applying a current between two electrodes. In this project, an ABEM Terrameter LS was used to measure a number of ERT-profiles using the gradient-array configuration. The fieldwork was performed at three locations on Zealand; Bagsværd, Gribskov, and Susåen. CPT data were only available for the area at Susåen and therefore the data obtained from this location is used for the correlation.

The fieldwork data was inverted using Res2DInv as a part of the preliminary assessment of the data. Subsequently the data from Susåen was inverted using Aarhus Workbench to include the CPT-data in the input model. The inverted profile was then optimized by removing incorrect measured resistivity as well as using an adjusted input model.

In conclusion the results show that correlation with CPT is a viable method to improve the ERT-profile with a priori data, as long as the stratigraphy of the ground does not change rapidly and there is a number of CPT sounding that can be used for quality assurance.

fields.title: Sonic Methods and Rock Mass Classification related to Tunnelling in Greenland
fields.abstract:
Present report presents results from field investigations carried out at the Tasersuaq hydropower project site
and laboratory measurements and tests at the Building & Construction School in Sisimiut.
Field investigations were carried out in the parts of the allready excavated tunnel system at the project site.
These investigations included refraction seismic surveys, engineering geological mapping and measurements of
Schmidt rebounds.
The investigations were conducted along a 90 m profile in what will be referred to as the access/maintenance
tunnel, and at a single site at what will be referred to as the pressure tunnel site, which is of interest since a
tunnel collapse happened within 25 m of this site. The investigations were restricted to be performed at tunnel
segments where the natural ventilation was sufficient to secure good air quality, since the ventilation system
was shut down due to the winter hiatus.
Further were samples from the tunnels retrieved to be tested under laboratory conditions, from which
reference data were obtained.
To supplement the samples taken from the field sites, already existing cores from the Sisimiut area were
selected to undergo the same laboratory testing as the samples from the actual site. The cores were selected to
resemble expected rock types from the hydropower site. In all are 6 petrologically different igneous and
metamorphic rock types considered in present report, including the sampled rock type from the hydropower
project site.
The seismic surveys were originally intended to have been performed as measurement of direct p- and s-wave
velocities on the tunnel walls. But this proved to be difficult to realize in practice, since only single-component
geophones were available. The alternative was to perform measurements of refracted p-waves, where
geophones were inserted into the tunnel floor. This yielded satisfactory results, and the 90 m profile and the
single spread were realized.
The engineering geological mapping was performed with the aim of both classifying the rock and discontinuities,
and to later calculate the failure envelope of the rock mass. The calculation of the rock mass failure envelope
was only possible for the pressure tunnel site, since only from here were the samples large enough to be
prepared into specimens which could be tested in unconfined compression as 50mm·50mm·100mm rectangular
prisms.
The software RocLab, which is a product available at www.rocscience.com, is used to apply the general Hoek-
Brown failure criterion on data from the pressure tunnel site.
The Schmidt hammer rebounds were intended to provide data for evaluating compressive strengths and degree
of weathering. Only for the pressure tunnel site was the Schmidt hammer rebounds valid, since the
access/maintenance tunnel walls were covered with droplets of shotcrete, which to some degree invalidated
the rebound measurements.
Previous investigations, performed during preinvestigations in relation to the hydropower project, will be
compared with the findings in present report. The previous investigations include borings, refractions seismic
profiling and surface mapping.
The laboratory measurements and tests performed on the samples and supplementary cored specimens
includes determination of bulk densities, p-wave velocities, point load indices, unconfined compressive
strengths and Brazilian indirect tensile strengths.
Bulk densities are combined with p-wave velocities to form dynamic elastic moduli, with which other obtained
parameters of the intact rock are compared. Here mainly the correlations with compressive strengths and static
moduli are of interest, since these the most relevant in an engineering sense.
The intact p-wave velocities of the from the field sampled rock type, form an upper bound for the in situ p-wave
velocities obtained from the refraction seismic surveys. When considering the square of the ratio between intact
and in situ p-wave velocities, a measure for the rock quality, specifically the RQD, is obtained.
These calculated rock qualities are then compared with actual tunnel mapping, performed by geologists from
Ístak, and is also compared with the tunnel mapping conducted in relation to present report.
The remaining tests, being point load testing and Brazilian tests, form a basis for evaluating the ratios of
compressive strength relative to indirect tensile strength, and compressive strength relative to point load index.
Further do the unconfined compressive strength and indirect tensile strength form the data basis for calculating
the friction angle and internal cohesion, which are determined from envelopes in different stress
representations.
The main conclusions from this report are:
There can be obtained a good correlation between velocities in rock obtained from seismic surveys, and
actually mapped rock quality descriptors, mainly the rock quality designation RQD. No zones of fatal
weakness in the investigated tunnels were identified from refraction seismic velocities, nor from
engineering geological mapping.
On a laboratory basis, the dynamic moduli obtained from cored and sampled specimens, and rock
properties like unconfined compressive strength and static moduli, follow an increasing trend when
correlated values are plotted against each other. The trend cannot be determined satisfactory only
utilizing the relatively small data set obtained in relation to this project; the inhomogeneous nature of
rock give rise to variance in the obtained data, which require a large data set for a more complete
understanding of the trend.

fields.title: Energieffektiv ventilation i Grønland: Undersøgelser og analyser af ventilering i et arktisk klima
Olieforurenet GTO-grund: Forureningstal og fremtidige anvendelsesmuligheder

Massebalance af gletcher
Tungmetaller i sedimenter

Sustainable handling of waste from shrimp processing in Sisimiut, Greenland
Should the GTO-site in Sisimiut, Greenland be remediated?
Remediation of an Oil-Contaminated Site in Sisimiut
Field Study of the Arctic Mining Industry with Focus on Acid Generation Prediction of Samples via Geochemical Static Tests
Utilizing energy from wastewater in the arctic
Establishment of a long-term site for permafrost thickness and temperature monitoring
Improvements of the organization and planning of the Greenlandic housing constructions by the use of prefabricated elements
Kompostering i Sisimiut
Active ex situ removal of oil in arctic soil
fields.abstract:
In 2012 hydrocarbon contaminated soil in Sisimiut, Greenland, was sieved and gathered in four different boxes for an ex situ remediation experiment. Only by adding nutrients and surplus heating from the local incineration plant, a low-cost technology is tested, so a possible method for treating oil-polluted soil can available to the municipality of Sisimiut.
The hydrocarbons in the soil are essentially heavy components, which from the result of the tests are more difficult to remediate. During the first months of the experiments, the light hydrocarbon components are remediated from the soil, in all four boxes. The heavier components require more time, and without any addition of heat it seems that they will not be remediated.
However, by adding heat the total hydrocarbon content of the soil is moderately decreasing over the two-year period.

fields.title: REDUCTION OF GLASS AND METAL FRACTIONS IN HOUSEHOLD WASTE BY PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN SISIMIUT
fields.abstract:
The municipality of Qeqqata, Greenland, implemented in 2012 the sorting of glass and metal from household waste, which was estimated in 2013 to have efficiency of 7-32% for glass and 5-23% for metal. This project attempted to enhance the efficiencyby implementing containers for glass/metal at home in the residential area Kussangasoq in the town Sisimiut combined with public participation strategies.
Interviews revealed that app. 93% of the residents would sort more with access to permanent containers, better waste management information and involvement in decision-makings. At the end of the 3-weeks fieldwork period the sorting efficiency had increased to app. 56% for glass and 43% for metal from resp. 7-32% and 5-23%. The residents of Kussangasoq suggested improving of the sorting of glass/metal by having containers at home, indoor bins for glass/metal, better campaigns that could involve TV-spots, home visits/open meetings, and involvement of the residents in the implementation.

fields.title: Sampling organic waste fractions for compost use in Sisimiut
fields.abstract: ABSTRACT: Composting of organic waste in Greenland is being researched as a means to decrease the amounts of waste to incineration plants or burned in open landfills. The incineration plant in Sisimiut among the other largest towns, cannot keep up with the growing amounts of waste generated by inhabitants, resulting in landfills growing, and incineration plants shutting down frequently due to higher maintenance needs. This study focuses on the amount and composition of organic waste generated in Sisimiut. Fieldwork was carried out over a two week period in august, sampling waste from the Kussangasoq households, Brugseni grocery outlet, and Sømandshjemmet hotel/restaurant. The total amount of organic waste sampled was 1470kg (71%), which was comprised of a (39%) vegetarian-fraction, an (25%) animal fraction and a (37%) structural materials fraction (e.g. wood, paper and cardboards), metal and glass (2%) was also sorted. Carbon to nitrogen estimates of the sampled organic waste fractions were high, suggesting that no significant amount of combustible materials need be removed from the general waste flow.

fields.title: Heavy metal investigation in marine sediments, biota and seawater during low tides in Ulkebugten, Sisimiut.
fields.abstract: The aim of this study is to investigate pollution of marine environment with heavy metals in Sisimiut, Greenland and to determine if their concentrations cause a threat to the aquatic environment. A number of samples were collected from the bay Ulkebugten, and from the coastline surrounding Sisimiut. The concentrations of Cd, Cr, Cu, Fe, Ni, Pb and Ti, in sediment, seawater, mussels and algae samples were investigated. Furthermore, wastewater samples were collected to shed light on this pollutant and know if heavy metals concentrations in untreated wastewater in Sisimiut are significant. The total concentrations were determined using ICP-OES (inductively coupled plasma - optical emission spectrometry). Metal concentrations in sediment samples were correlated with organic matter content and loss on ignition. Samples collected in the inner part of the bay shows elevated values of heavy metals compared to other regions. Results indicate a negative impact of the direct discharge of untreated wastewater on marine environment.

fields.title: Design Considerations for the Creation of a New Industrial Harbour for Maniitsoq, Greenland
fields.abstract: Alcoa is prospecting various locations where to place their next aluminium smelter. One of the locations is the island of Maniitsoq which is located on the west coast of Greenland. This study has made a basic approximation of how a new industrial port in Maniitsoq could be, based on the hydraulic and infrastructure requirements. The new industrial harbour will be placed on the North West corner of the island as it provides the easiest and safest access route for the vessels to call at the port. An access channel of minimum dimensions width 150.4m and depth 13.9m is provided by the existing seabed characteristics and distance between the Maniitsoq and neighbouring islands, regardless of tidal elevation. Analysed wind data shows that it does not reach above critical speeds of 18 m/s more than 1% over a time series of more than 50 years and a dominant direction from North-East to South-East is favourable. The wave height of 1.2m in the port area is too high for the safe (un)loading of containers and a breakwater or other measure to reduce the wave height is required. Various Queueing Theory models have been accessed and one berth for the dry bulk and container vessels respectively was necessary to fully service the port with low expected waiting times. A hinterland area of 54,350m2 to support the landside infrastructure is readily available at the proposed location. As a basis for further investigation this study may be applicable to get a basic understanding of the topic.

fields.title: Hydrologic Study of the Aqqutikitsoq Glacier and its Catchment: An Attempt to Describe Storage Processes
fields.abstract: Energy production in Greenland relies to an increasing extent on hydropower. Therefore, the aim of this study was to investigate and understand hydrologic processes associated with a catchment including a glacier at Andenfjorden, Western Greenland, similar to other Greenlandic catchments used for hydropower applications. During a 12 day field campaign in August, 2014, five discharge measurements by means of salt dilution experiments were conducted and used to establish a discharge-stage rating curve, rain was recorded by 11 rain gauges that were distributed over the entire catchment, and glacier melt was estimated.. The average discharge was ~2.9m³/s and discharge rates up to ~19.4m³/s were recorded during a storm event. The total precipitation was 58.3mm of which 49.7mm precipitated during the storm event. Furthermore, melt contribution from the Aqqutikitsoq glacier was ~0.94m³/s in average and up to ~2.3m³/s at high temperatures. The lag time between the start of a precipitation event and increased discharge was ~3hours while the lag time between increased melt rates and increased discharge was ~12hours. A description of glacier storages processes was though not possible due to too big time steps of precipitation measurements. The water balance revealed that 53.6% of total discharge can be explained by the investigated glacier melt and precipitation while 46.4% comes presumably from an unmonitored source. It can be interpreted as contribution from melt of ice-cored moraines and snow packs. Nevertheless, separation of contributions from the different hydrologic processes is subjected to uncertainty.

fields.title: Design and implementation of a data logger for permafrost temperature long-term monitoring in Arctic regions
fields.abstract: This project describes the design, implementation and installation of a multichannel temperature data logger with SD card storage for permafrost monitoring. The data logger implemented is a low-power consumption 32-channel temperature data logger with a precision of 0.022ºC and a resolution of 0.006ºC controlled by an ATmega microcontroller programmed to record data from each channel every hour. Since the data logger is designed to be installed in Arctic regions, tests to verify the stability of the system under different temperature have been performed reaching successful results. A sensors’ string has been built to be assembled with the data logger for a final compact, self-contained and reliable system.

fields.title: Development of a software application to monitor soil temperature under arctic conditions
fields.abstract: Permafrost variation can alter ecosystem, destroy infrastructures and even release enough gasses to seriously affect the climate change. In order to predict and model the future changes in the permafrost a temperature monitoring station has been built. It consists of two main elements, a data logger which process and stores the data and a string with thermistors on it which takes the measurements of the ground at different depths. The work has been divided into two sections, the hardware and the software part, being this last one the one this article is about. During the construction of the data logger some problems has arisen related to the initial bootloading of the microprocessor and the communication with the external clock that made us took the decision of modifying slightly the code. The obtained lab results showed that the system was taking data with the desired accuracy and storing it in the SD card. The station was installed in Ilulissat (Greenland) on summer 2014 as a part of a new CALM initiative grid.

fields.title: Study of the oil residue from in-situ burning in the Arctic
fields.abstract: The possible oil production and the increase of ship traffic within the next years in Greenland could provoke an oil spill with serious environmental impacts. Therefore, effective remediation techniques have to be studied and one of these methods is in-situ burning. That is burning of the spilled oil, in case of an accident, on the water surface. The aim of this study was to determine the composition of the residue after burning, its properties and the efficiency of burning under Arctic conditions. In-situ burning experiments with two different types of crude oil and ice were performed in Greenland and at DTU fire-lab using a custom-built set up. Gas chromatography analysis of residue samples was conducted as well as estimation of efficiency by weighing the remaining residue. The main results of this study were that almost all the light components of the oil were removed during the burning and that the efficiency of the outdoor experiments in Greenland was significantly increased compared to the indoor experiments. Also, the density of the burn residue was always lower than water, thus it did not sink and was easily collected, especially when burning with ice. The results showed that in-situ burning can be considered an appropriate method for facing an oil spill in Arctic environment with great efficiency.

fields.title: Soot production and particle size distribution from in situ burning of crude oils
fields.abstract: In situ burning has proven to be an effective response for oil spills in Arctic conditions. However the incomplete combustion of oil, due to an incomplete chemical reaction between the fuel and oxygen, lead to the production of solid and gaseous products, such as particulate matter (soot), polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Several studies have suggested a link between the presence of these compounds and several diseases; of high concern are the particles smaller than 10 μm (PM10) that can penetrate deep in the lungs, hence the importance to understand the key parameters affecting particulate production and size. The aim of this study was to evaluate the influence of oil viscosity, pool size diameter and the presence of ice on the production of soot and size of the particles emitted. Two oils were used: DUC and REBCO, with a viscosity of 5 cP and 16 cP respectively. The scale effect was studied on two pools with diameters of 15 and 26 cm. The analysis was divided in three phases: a first outdoor phase performed in Greenland, where in situ burning experiments were performed using both oils and pools, in fresh and salt water and with the presence of ice. The smoke was collected on 2 μm pore size filters and later analysed. The same experiments were later performed in indoor conditions and the concentration of carbon monoxide was measured using optical analysis. In the last phase, the soot collected on the filters was observed with the help of the scanning electron microscope (SEM). A positive correlation between the pool size and the amount of soot produced was observed, connected with a peak in carbon monoxide production during the vigorous burning phase, while viscosities has shown different behaviour depending on the pool size. The particles size seems to be independent of both the viscosity and the pool diameter. However, the presence of PM10 was observed during combustion in ice affected water

fields.title: In-Situ Burning Efficiencies of Water-Crude Oil Emulsions
fields.abstract: The effectiveness of in-situ burning as a response to marine oil spills depends largely on the burning potential of the oil slick. The emulsification of crude oil, for example through the uptake of water in the oil slick due to oil-water interactions, is a time dependent process that negatively influences the burning efficiency and the ignitability. The aim of this study was to determine the effect of the emulsification of crude oil on the burning efficiency, which is defined as the mass of oil (in percentages) removed from the surface of the water. Two crude oils (DUC and REBCO) were used to make water-in-oil emulsions with 20 wt% intervals of water (i.e. 0, 20, 40, 60 and 80 wt% of water) to study the effect of the added water on the burning efficiency. Outdoor burning experiments were conducted in Sisimiut, Greenland, and the results were complimented and compared with laboratory experiments. The burning efficiency showed an inverse linear correlation with the water content, varying between 68-26% (indoor) and 77-41% (outdoor) for 0wt% to 80wt% water content DUC. For REBCO, the efficiencies were 59-2% (indoor) and 70-60 % (outdoor) for 0wt% to 80wt% and 0wt% to 40wt% water content, respectively. Higher burning efficiencies for the outdoor experiments were likely caused by the fact that the burning was wind-aided. Still, this did not affect the observed correlation between the burning efficiency and water content. The results clearly showed that the emulsification of the crude oil has a negative impact on the burning efficiency and thus limits the response time for which in-situ burning might be an effective method to clean marine oil spills.

fields.title: Energy performance of sustainable home in Greenland
fields.abstract:
Lack of sufficient ventilation in buildings in Arctic climates contributes to construction damage and health problems in the occupants and ventilating directly with air at the ambient temperature increases the energy consumption of a building. Despite the current state of knowledge even the newly constructed buildings have insufficient ventilation. 
Recently, brand new ventilation unit together with an air-quality monitoring system was installed in a newly build single family house in Sisimiut. Greenland. The monitoring system is programmed to measure the temperature, relative humidity and CO2 concentration in a few spots inside of the building. During the field work in Greenland in August 2014 the data transfer between the ventilation unit and data logger was established and the logger was programmed to upload the data to the FTP server accessible through the internet.
The aim of the subsequent investigation was to compare the performance of the newly constructed energy-efficient single family house with the performance of a standard house of this kind in Greenlandic conditions. To do so, a model of the building was created in a simulation software and the simulations were run to estimate the energy consumption and indoor climate parameters inside the building. The same simulation was made  for the typical building in the same shape and the results were compared to evaluate how introduced improvements (better insulation and mechanical ventilation system) influence the energy consumption and indoor climate. Additionally, the possibility of using ventilation as the only heating source for the building was investigated.
The yearly energy consumption for space heating in case of the analyzed building is about 2/3 of that of the house of the same shape with U-values fulfilling the minimal requirements of Greenlandic Building Regulations 2006. The issue of overheating was also discussed. The obtained results show also, that if the ventilation system is to be the only heating system in the building, it has to be designed specifically for that purpose.

fields.title: Evaluating Air Traffic Noise Impact on Sisimiut Community
fields.abstract: This manuscript presents the methods and results of an evaluation of the impact of air traffic noise in the Greenlandic town of Sisimiut. Quantitative and qualitative data were recorded in the summer 2014. During the fieldwork, the sound pressure level produced by aircrafts, arriving and departing to and from Sisimiut airport, was measured at 9 different locations in order to identify any possible influence of air traffic noise on inhabitants’ psychology, or in the long-term, to the their health. In order to obtain the necessary information and evaluate the impact of the desired noise source on the residents a survey was conducted. The participants of the survey were 18 inhabitants and they answered a questionnaire, which was designed to assess their perception of noise associated with air traffic noise. The measurement method that was used was based on the ISO 1996 standard. The obtained data and the analysis gave results which showed that the residents are aware of the noise produced by the aircrafts but the level of annoyance is relatively low. The measured sound pressure levels are elevated, especially at the locations close to the marine port. Though, the fact that the events are not so often and the routes that the aircrafts follow are not specific renders the annoyance from the air traffic noise in the area insignificant.

fields.title: Solutions for sustainable and healthy green buildings in Greenland
fields.abstract:
Implementing sustainable building solutions while increasing the amount of livable
spaces in Greenland has a significant importance. Not only in order to provide energy
efficient buildings or to introduce innovative housing solutions but also to create
higher environmental quality and enlarge living spaces for people living in the Arctic.
The study examines the possibilities of creating an atrium area in Sisimiut, that is
built in between two existing building blocks. The proposal uses passive sustainable
design strategies in order to obtain indoor comfort by avoiding over heating and
striving for reducing heat losses. Such an unheated glass covered semi-indoor semioutdoor
space, constructed to existing building structure, is a matter of rethinking the
traditional usage of atriums which makes it a sustainable building solution that has
several qualities under arctic climate conditions. The project is aiming for obtaining
indoor comfort conditions in this space whitout any active mechanical system only by
using passive solutions by the geometry, orientation, materials, heat gains both from
neighbouring buildings and solar radiation, with optimised solar shadings, while
reducing heat losses. The study uses the building energy symulation program IDA
ICE to simulate the changing indoor conditions through a year time, examines the sun
path, solar radiation, shadings and related external conditions by Autodesk Ecotect,
and investigates the geometry and building solutions with the usage of ArchiCad and
Rhinoceros.

fields.title: Use of Greenlandic Clay as Filler in Concrete
fields.abstract: This paper investigates the opportunity to use local clay as a substitute for cement in concrete produced for industrial use in Greenland. This could potentially reduce the amount of imported cement as Greenland is further developed, thereby reducing costs and creating local jobs. The investigation was carried out in four phases over a period of two semesters: Literature investigation, data sampling in Greenland, data processing and finally concrete casting and testing. In the literature study, several studies were found indicating that there may be some merit to the approach of substituting cement with Greenlandic clay due to the special characteristics of the clay in Greenland due to the cold climate. One of the studies actually pointed to increased concrete strength when using Greenland clay filler in low concentrations. The data sampling phase was done in two locations in Greenland with rich clay concentrations: Sisimiut and Kangerlussuaq. In the subsequent data processing phase, it was determined that the material characteristics of the clay in these two locations in Greenland are very different. Only the Sisimiut clay has the potential to be a suitable filler in concrete due to high salt concentrations in the Kangerlussuaq clay, which increases the risk of corrosion of the steel reinforcement in concrete. In the final phase, mortar samples with varying amounts of clay filler from Sisimiut were cast and then tested for compressive and flexural strength as well as porosity and density. The test results showed that the introduction of the clay filler as a cement replacement reduces the compressive and flexible strength of the concrete. There may however, be a business case to use the filler in small concentrations (less than 5%) for low strength industrial use, where the reduced strength is acceptable but further studies will be required to confirm this hypothesis.

fields.title: Greenlandic Clay In Concrete Design
fields.abstract: ABSTRACT: This paper presents the use of Greenlandic clay as a filler material in concrete. The building materials on Greenland are very sparse and one of the local resources which still has a unresolved potential is the Greenlandic clay. The assembling of clay samples have been carried out near the cities of Kangerlussuaq and Sisimiut in Western Greenland, with the future intent of a clay production facility. The clay has been used in mortar samples to replace some of the sand in the mortar mixture in order to achieve a more dens and stronger mortar composition. The clay has been tested for classical geotechnical investigations. The mortar samples have been tested for flexural and compressive strength, which have been compared to reference mortar samples, without the clay replacement. In order to achieve a more insightful perspective of the Greenlandic clay, more test have to be carried out and more knowledge about the chemical composition is of great relevance.

fields.title: New harbor in Kangerlussuaq. Field investigations and utilization of existing materials
fields.abstract:
The international airport of Greenland is located in Kangerlussuaq, making
it an important connection point for tourists and transportation of goods. However, the existing harbor in Kangerlussuaq experiences major challenges in the form of extensive
sedimentation of glaciofluvial sediments transported by rivers from the inland
ice to the inner parts of the fjord. These sediment layers reduce the water depth and prevent
container- and cruiseships to dock, imposing large additional maintenance costs,
and inefficient operability. Through engineering geological field and lab investigations, a possible new harbor location around 10 km further out the fjord near Hancock Pynt, has been investigated. The onshore area was found to be highly suitable for a harbor
support area, where a sub-base thickness of 1.8 m with gravel cover-layer was found adequate for the calculated design loads. Existing sediment deposits at the location are reusable as construction material and may reduce construction costs. Bathymetry investigations
indicate however that measures must be taken to increase the water depth,
and the offshore sediments were found not suitable as support for foundations.

fields.title: Urban Environmental Sustainability Assessment of city Maniitsoq, Greenland
fields.abstract: The urban environmental sustainability assessment is an essential step in sustainable development as it provides an overview of environmental conditions and supports decision making in planning and development of a city. The aim of this study was to assess the environmental dimension of sustainability of isolated harbor city of Maniitsoq, Greenland. Environmental sustainability assessment model targeting Arctic region was developed considering local features of the city. Results indicated a low performance in urban environmental sustainability. It was found that number of activities in the city are not monitored and it hinders the evaluation process. Also, it was argued that existing challenges are associated with social, institutional and economical dimensions in the city. That led to a conclusion that the harbor area, marine resources, education prospects, image and identity of the city should be seen as the most important assets of the city in order to assist progress. Lastly, the findings suggest that there is a possibility of obtaining urban environmental conditions from the assessment model and recommends that more in depth research of urban sustainability appraisal in Arctic regions should be carried out.

fields.title: Ice Albedo measurements on the Aqqutikitsoq glacier, Greenland
Glacier volume estimation
Thermal Insulation for Greenlandic Buildings
fields.abstract:
Due to the artic climate Greenlandic houses has twice as many heating days as in Denmark. The houses are build recording to former Danish regulations which is insufficient based on the climate differences.
The aim for this project was to study the used thermal insulation in Greenland and new ideas for exterior insulation. This was done by categorising advantages and disadvantages of the different materials and by identifying challenges of implementing new materials. The local workers views on the handling of the materials were taken into account for extensive perspective.
The thermal insulation materials used today in Greenland is glass wool for exterior walls and rock wool for ground slabs. Polyurethane foam insulation and expanded polystyrene properties are compared to the already used products to investigate possibilities for more suitable materials regarding gained insulation volume related to transported unit volume of 1 m3. Based on the transport there is motivation for introducing the expanding materials as the transported volume gives 25–72.7 times more insulation material and the transported volume of regular mineral wool gives 0.33–0.7 times more.
Furthermore the possibility of producing own insulation materials in Greenland is investigated such as paper insulation and seaweed. Lack of encouragement from the authorities and the very low transportation prices due to the weight of insulation materials, makes it difficult to compete on this market.
It is suggested to focus on how to implement other thermal insulation materials instead of which materials to implement.

fields.title: Estimating Volume and Volume Change of a Small Greenlandic Glacier with Geophysical Methods
fields.abstract:
This report investigates the Aqqutikitsoq glacier in Southwest Greenland near
Sisimiut. The current ice thickness distribution and total volume of the glacier
is estimated based on ice thickness measurements using ground penetrating
radar (GPR) and GPS obtained during fieldwork in August 2014. Furthermore
the change in ice thickness and volume is estimated by analysing the vertical
elevation difference of digital elevation models (DEMs) from 1985 and 2012.
The GPR measurements of the glacier subsurface are processed in the software
ReflexW providing an estimate of the ice thickness. Together with the corresponding
coordinates this provide a three-dimensional data set of the glacier
which is interpolated using MATLAB linear interpolation between the data
points and the glacier perimeter. From model A, which is based on ice thickness
measurements of high certainty, the total glacier volume is estimated to be 1.26
(0.07)  108 m3. From model B, which includes a larger amount of ice thickness
data but also data of higher uncertainty, the volume is estimated to be 1.40
(0.08)108 m3. The results are given for a 95% confidence interval calculated
only from intersecting GPR measurements. It can not be concluded unambiguously
that model B is better than model A, however model B is preferred as it
includes a larger amount of data without increasing the residuals compared to
model A. The DEMs are corrected for systematic bias by a mean error of 4.9 m
and a standard deviation of 2.4 m. The volume loss is 1.99 (0.71)  107 m3
for the area where both DEMs are considered reliable (51.2%). The volume loss
for the remaining 48.8% of the glacier area is estimated to be 1.44 (0.65)107
m3 by extrapolating data using a linear regression model. The mean thickness
decrease is 12.0 (4.7) m. The thinning of the glacier is most pronounced at
the glacier tongue where a maximum thickness decrease of 37.1 m is found.
The total volume loss from 1985 to 2012 is estimated to 3.43 (1.36)  107
m3 corresponding to a volume decrease between 12.9% and 25.5% relative to
1985. Despite uncertainties it is concluded that the Aqqutikitsoq glacier shows
considerable thinning and retreat between 1985 and 2012.

fields.title: Digital Elevation Model Reconstruction of a Glaciarized Basin Using Land-Based Structure from Motion
fields.abstract: In a climate change context, volume variations of glaciers can be efficiently evaluated by comparison of Digital Elevation Models (DEM) of the ice surface, taken at different time frames. However, traditional methods of DEM reconstruction lack either in resolution or they are costly, considering the remoteness of certain basins. This study aims for testing a method called Structure from Motion (SfM) for high resolution DEM reconstruction on a 2.7 km2 glaciarized basin in the Aqqutikitsoq mountain range, Western Greenland. The SfM method is capable to recreate the 3D structure of an object using a set of highly overlapping pictures covering the entire surface of the object itself. This concept is applied to the Aqqutikitsoq glacier, which was mapped using a consumer grade camera in August 2014. The 3D model was obtained by processing with the software Agisoft Photoscan 249 pictures taken from four main viewpoints. The georeferencing was done using 50 Ground Control Points (GCPs) acquired during the ground survey. The GPS coordinates of the GCPs were obtained using a Post Processing Kinematic (PPK) method, which reaches centimeter precision. The results show that the glacier surface is mapped with a resolution of 0.79 m and a elevation accuracy of 0.73 m. Considering the level of the equipment involved, the high resolution achieved, the logistic and technical ease of the method, it can be stated that SfM represents a powerful and efficient technology for DEM reconstruction suitable for glaciers located in remote areas.

fields.title: Overførselstunneler til vandkraftværker i permafrostområder
fields.abstract: Issues surrounding ice forming in transfer tunnels from hydropower plants, in permafrost areas. The project includes modeling of temperature conditions in situations respectively water- and air-filled transfer tunnels with and without water flow. The project will also assess the practical design measures to prevent ice forming in the transfer tunnels. The risk of a totally frozen tunnel not even for the coldest circumstances, to ensure against freezing at intake and outlet 3D analysis is advisable

fields.title: Recommendation of components for an Autonomous Automatic Mass-balance Station (AAMS)
New Harbor in Kangerlussuaq, Western Greenland. Wave- and Flow Modeling for the Analysis of Ship Movements and Marina Design
fields.abstract:
Extensive water depth challenges due to glaciouvial sediments outside of the existing harbor in Kangerlussuaq, prevents larger ships to dock. Thus cruise- and container ships transporting cargo and passengers to and from the settlement, are forced to anchor at deep
sea some distance away from the harbor. This is a time consuming and costly solution, as containers and passengers must be transported to the existing harbor by smaller watercraft. Qeqqata municipality has therefore initiated plans regarding the construction of a new harbor and adjacent marina at a different location, where the sedimentation challenges are less severe. A ledge near Hancock Pynt, located around 10 km from the existing harbor, has been suggested as a suitable location. The environmental conditions related to the new harbor and marina have been investigated through the use of the numerical modeling suite MIKE 21. Simulations of the hydrodynamic and wave conditions in the inner part of Søndre Strømfjord and outside the harbor area, were used to assess the best suitable
location of the marina. Also, the design of protection measures in terms of a 
floating breakwater was determined based on these fi ndings and previous model tests. Design widths of 4.2 m, 4.9 m and 13.5 m for a prism-, catamaran- and tire assembly type floating breakwater respectively, are suggested in order to maintain a moderate wave climate for head sea conditions in the marina, located to the east of Hancock Pynt. The wave conditions outside of the proposed harbor were found to mainly consist of short-period waves. The harbor downtime related to the influence of these waves was investigated and
found to be within acceptable limits (less than 1 week per year). Further analysis of the influence of long-period waves and swell, indicates that the proposed location is highly suitable for a future harbor.

fields.title: New habor in Kangerlussuaq, western Greenlnad - Environmental  actions analysis  and preliminary harbor design
fields.abstract:
In 2008 the Greenlandic inhabitants voted to become became more self-governing. As a part of the increased independence the block grant that Greenland receives from Denmark was frozen. This means that Greenland’s GDP decreases a little bit each year due to inflation. Therefore there is a pressure on Greenland to be self sufficient, but the island suffer infrastructural problems: no roads between towns, large distances and few access gateways to the country. One of the most impor- tant access gateways is Greenland’s International Airport in Kangerlussuaq. The airport has a road connection to a harbor, which means that Kangerlussuaq is a connection point between the greenlandic ship lines and international air traffic. The problem is that the water depth outside the current harbor in Kangerlussuaq
is too shallow for large ships. This means that cruise and cargo ships must anchor far out in the fjord, and send containers and tourists by small vessels, which is not cost efficient. As a direct consequence, it takes up to 4 days to unload a container ship, compared to 6 hours if the ship were docked at the harbor.
A solution to this problem is to make a new harbor. A new location is found 10 km further out in the fjord, with sufficient depth. It is believed that the location should not have any problems due to sedimentation in 100 years. The challenge is the remoteness of the location, and a seabed consisting of weak material. Measure- ments indicates that the bedrock is at close proximity and inclined, which makes it challenging to find a suitable and durable construction.
By investigating the environmental actions at the location, it was seen that the new location is sheltered from both wind and currents. The currents at the location were in the order of 0.12 m/s at most, while the wind returned a design wave heigh of 3.1 m. To meet the challenging geotechnical conditions and with the base in the governing environmental actions, a sheet pile retaining wall was found to the most cost efficient for for a new harbor. From the preliminary design calculations it was found that the design moment at the sheet pile wall was in the order of 1150 kNm, which means that the solution is highly plausible for the site. The solution were also customized for the location, by optimizing the use of on-site materials to avoid under water work.

fields.title: Determining Snow Depth Distribution From Unmanned Aerial Vehicles and Digital Photogrammetry
fields.abstract: Determining snow depth spatial distribution is crucial not only for serving civil purposes related to drinking water supply or hydropower generation, but also for several applications in snow, hydrology and environmental research. However, snow depth results to be extremely variable both in space and time. Consequently, traditional and state-of-the-art snow monitoring methodologies are not always able to capture such a high spatial variability over time without highly expensive solutions. In the present work a new methodology is presented that aims to propose a solution to the problem by taking advantage of two low-cost and emerging technologies in a geoscience research context; Structure from Motion (SfM) digital photogrammetry and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs). The asset of the combination between these technologies is that they can provide accurate and high resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) of large areas, at low-running costs and at a reduced effort. The proposed method would profit of this asset and perform a subtraction between georeferenced snow surfaces (snow DEMs) and their corresponding underlying topographies (topography DEMs), thus providing snow depth distribution maps. In order to test the feasibility and efficiency of the presented method on a small scale level, six different snow covered areas were surveyed in the mentioned above context. The areas ranged from 900 to 51,000 m^2 and two were located near Longyearbyen, Svalbard and four near Andenfjorden, West Greenland. The surveys differed in terms of snow surface type, underlying topography complexity, luminance conditions and equipment used in order to assess an applicability range for the method. The results are presented as six snow depth distribution maps and are validated by comparing estimated snow depths to probed snow depths over a set quality control points. Depending on the area, the average difference between probed and estimated snow depth varied from 0.01 m for the best case to 0.19 m for the worst case, meanwhile the spatial resolution ranged from 0.06 to 0.1 m. The error sources for each case are thoroughly investigated and it was assessed that the error can be further mitigated by georeferencing the DEMs using common ground control points visible in both the snow surface and the corresponding underlying topography. In the tests performed, the method did not result particularly limited by any specific surface characterization of the area or any survey condition. Even though it was tested over small scale areas, by considering these preliminary results the method presents the potential to be a simplified procedure that allows repeat-mapping of snow dynamics while mitigating running costs and without resigning at obtaining high accuracies and resolutions.

fields.title: Snow Distribution Statistical Modelling and UAV-borne Remote Sensing of Snow Reflectance in the Arctic
fields.abstract:
The present study is part of a project that aims at mapping snow depth and snow optical
properties using Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) -borne digital photogrammetry. It is organized
in two parts, the  rst part aims at estimating snow distribution from snow depth point
measurements by means of regression tree models, and the second at extracting Hemispherical
Directional Re
ectance Factor of snow from images taken by a digital re
ex camera  xed to a
UAV.
The objective of the  rst part is to assess the capacity of regression tree models and of a set
of predictors to distribute snow over an area from point measurements and at testing whether
they could be used in the future for high resolution snow depth data acquired by UAV-borne
photogrammetry. In four sites around Longyearbyen in Svalbard, Norway, snow depth was
measured by manual probing or Ground Penetrating Radar. Then a regression tree model was
built for each site and for two Digital Elevation Models (5 m and 50 m resolution) to predict
snow depth from elevation slope, two wind exposure indexes Sx and Sb, and a radiation index.
For all sites except one the 5 m models showed higher R2 than the 50 m ones indicating that
regression trees successfully model snow depth at a small scale. The 5 m snow distribution
models give R2 ranging from 0.39 (4 snow classes) to 0.67 (2 snow classes) which is satisfactory
compared to previous studies using regression trees. Most snow distribution models were found
to be site speci c and could not be applied on other sites. It was addressed to dierences of
snow distribution processes or to the eect of dierent snow depth sampling methods. The snow
distribution model built in Longyearbyen and snow density data were used to estimate total Snow
Water Equivalent (SWE) stored in the snow cover of Longyearbreen glacier. The regression tree
model estimated a total SWE value of 8:13  2:90  105 m3 and showed an improved precision
when compared to the results of a constant snow depth model and of an elevation gradient
model. Errors and limitations of the present modelling framework are discussed and suggestions
are given for further studies.
In the second part, a method to estimate snow re
ectance from UAV-borne digital images
is investigated. The approach presented, uses the digital camera to measure luminance in a
scene and then estimates the re
ectance of a surface by comparing its luminance to the one
of a surface of known re
ectance in the picture. The calibration of the camera simply relates
the camera response to variations in a target brightness,  nding a linear relationship between
luminance and pixel intensity. It has the advantage of requiring no speci c equipment and to
avoid the complex calculation of camera spectral sensitivity. Vignetting eect was corrected
The camera accuracy is assessed by investigating shot noise and dark current. In the  eldwork
conditions, shot noise is found to be the most relevant source of noise and sucient exposure
of the pictures is recommended to reduce its eect. The method was tested during a  eldwork
campaign nearby Sisimiut, West Greenland. The UAV is 
own vertically up to 7.6 meters and
17 pictures are used to estimate the the re
ectance of a snow patch and of a 10% re
ective
validation surface. The estimated re
ectance values of the snow patch range from 0.97 to 0.98
with an uncertainty of 0.04 to 0.08. This data could not be compared to other  eld measurement
because of human mistake in the spectroradiometer measurement of the snow patch re
ectance.
The estimation of the validation surface re
ectance showed that a minimum number of pixels
are necessary to determine accurately the re
ectance of a surface. Based on a  rst estimation
of this threshold, the estimation of the validation surface re
ectance gives a Root Mean Square
Error of 0.05 which is relatively high compared to the surface real re
ectance. It is attributed to
the low brightness of the validation surface which increases noise. The necessity of a reference
surface in the picture is discussed and suggestions for future work are given.

fields.title: Vægbygning I Grønland
Gletcherprojekt
Effektivisering af eksisterende affaldssorteringsmuligheder i Sisimiut
Fiskenet som armering i beton
Det Moderne Tørvehus
Analyse af spildevand i Kangerlussuaq
Rensningsanlæg i Kangerlussuaq
Fiberarmering af beton - fiskenet som fiberearmering i beton
Tang som isolerings materiale
Properties of bricks produced from Greenlandic marine sediments
fields.abstract:
This thesis investigated the possibility of a local brick production from fine grained marine sediments in the
proximity of Sisimiut, Greenland. The assessment is based on the physical and mechanical properties of clay
bricks concerning the resistance to the harsh, Arctic weather conditions, together with an identification of a
suitable production method.
Samples of fine grained marine sediments were collected near the towns, Sisimiut and Kangerlussuaq, on
the Greenlandic west coast, and tested with respect to the geological properties. The results revealed a fine
grained, low plasticity, silty clay with evenly distributed grain sizes. A screening of the mineralogy (via X-ray
diffraction - XRD) and the chemical composition of the marine sediment samples was carried out to ensure
homogeneity and investigate if the marine sediment occurrences had high contents of unwanted substances such
as sulphur, organic matter and salts. The results showed low contents of both sulphur and carbon, whereas an
unexpectedly high content of chlorine was found. This may cause problems such as surface efflorescence on
the fired bricks and corrosion of the kiln during firing. The XRD revealed minerals as feldspar and quartz,
and the qualitative mineralogy was found to be very similar to those found in previous studies of Greenlandic
marine sediments.
After the preliminary investigations, a laboratory-scale study was made on fired brick pellets (d  20 mm, h 
3 mm) with respect to shrinkage and water absorption, and of fired miniature bricks (545460 mm3) with
respect to compressive strength and water absorption. The results were compared with ASTM requirements
for building bricks to classify their resistance to damage by freezing.
Productions of brick pellets were carried out to investigate the influence of variables such as firing temperature
(900 􀀀 1050 C), firing time (6 h, 3:5 days), forming pressure (20, 47 MPa), initial forming water content (10,
15 %) and content of granite waste (CR) (10 􀀀 20 %), in order to identify the most appropriate composition
and production procedure.
The results showed that the firing temperature and forming pressure have a large influence on the durability
properties and that an addition of CR induces lower firing temperatures and reduced firing shrinkage and water
absorption. Moreover, no significant difference in properties was observed for pellets fired with a fast firingcycle
at DTU and with a slow firing-cycle at Wienerberger.
Miniature bricks were formed with a pressure of 20 MPa and fired at 1020 C for 3:5 days at the brickwork
Wienerberger Tegl (Helsinge, Denmark). The study of miniature bricks showed that the water absorption
was too high after 24 h of submersion in cold water for weathering grade SW. It was concluded that the firing
temperature needed to be increased in order to obtain a more durable brick-type, suitable for the Arctic climate.

fields.title: Accuracy of Digital Elevation Model by Structure from Motion using Aerial Imagery
fields.abstract: This paper demonstrates the achievable accuracy of a Digital Elevation Model (DEM) produced by Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) in the Arctic for the purpose of quantifying permafrost degradation over time, and the steps necessary for error estimation. The area (ca. 200 m ×100 m), popularly known as the Thermokarst valley in Sisimiut, Greenland, is surveyed using aerial images shot from a UAV. The images are post processed using sophisticated Structure from Motion (SfM) algorithms in a commercial photogrammetric processing software package. The reconstructed DEM is slightly biased in terms of elevations because the SfM algorithms are influenced by the low-lying Arctic tundra in the area. It is demonstrated that the error estimate of the DEM must be based on a separate set of measured positions, as a cross-validation based approach on the ground control points does not reveal this bias. The vertical RMSE =4.06 cm, obtained from the validation points, serve as the representative error estimate of the DEM. Thus, it is demonstrated that it is possible to reconstruct DEMs, that can be applied as a tool to quantify permafrost degradation, although this requires long-term repeated surveys.

fields.title: change title
Monitoring the Snow Shedding on Arctic Photovoltaic Modules
fields.abstract: A monitoring system, consisting of a boxed and waterproof Raspberry Pi camera, was installed at two different sites in Sisimiut monitoring the snow shed on solar modules. The two installation sites have roof mounted solar modules with different tilt angles. This study’s aim is to set up the monitoring system to collect enough data to see haw the tilt angle of a solar module relates to snow shed and annual production loss. A possible model is one that expresses the annual loss in percentage of produced kWh as a function of annual snowfall. The first part of the data collected from the Raspberry Pi at the setup with the lowest tilt angle, shows that the snow does not shed from the modules at all, and thus signifies that a general model cannot be applied, because the shedding is strongly influenced by site specific factors.

fields.title: Hydrologic  characterization  of  a  glacierized  subcatchment  in Western Greenland using field measurements
fields.abstract: ydropower  as  a  source  of  energy  in  glacierized  regions  has  become increasingly  important  in  Greenland  in  later  years.  In  order  to  ensure  a  durable  and sustainable  management  of  hydropower  stations,  proper  understanding  of  hydrologic processes  in  the  catchment  is  essential.  This  study  uses simple  field  methods  to characterize  the  water  balance  at  the  terminus  of  the  glacier  Aqquitkitsoq,  at  519 m.a.s.l.  A  field  campaign  was  conducted  over  12  days  in  August  2015  measuring discharge,  water  level,  as  well  as  precipitation,  wind  speed and  temperature  at  camp level  (36.6  m.a.s.l.).  A  total  of 60  mm  rain  was  recorded  during  the  period.  A discharge-water  level  rating  curve  was  constructed  leading  to  simulated  discharge ranging between 0.14 and 2.00 m3/s. The water balance for the catchment resulted in a residual  volume  of  19,542  m3  or  3.8  %  of  the  total  discharge,  which  could  be attributed   to   uncertainties,   related   to   especially   precipitation   measurements. A continuous  contribution  of  0.4  m3/s  as  well  as  diurnal  fluctuations  were  attributed to melt processes. The results highlight the advantage of characterizing flow exiting the glacier  as  unknown  uncertainties  observed  in  previous  studies  were  greatly  reduced. In further studies, climate data from the catchment, and especially the glacier, should be  collected.  Furthermore  closer  investigation  of  melt  processes  may  improve  the understanding of the storage processes in the glacier.

fields.title: Wastewater treatment potentials in Kangerlussuaq: Characterisation of flow and chemical loadings
fields.abstract: Historically, wastewater treatment has been non-existing or insufficient in Arctic regions. Qeqqata municipality, Greenland, has decided to construct a full scale mechanical/chemical wastewater treatment plant in the settlement Kangerlussuaq. The aim of this study was to determine flow characteristics and chemicals loadings in order to facilitate the dimensioning of this plant. Unlikely the majority of Greenlandic settlements, Kangerlussuaq is sewered with wastewater being discharged from two outlets. This allowed for representative flow measuring and sampling. Flow was measured continuously with v-notch weirs using ultrasonic data loggers. The average flow was 175 m3/d and the hourly peak factor was 1.5. Additional stormwater can enter the sewer system hence potentially increasing the peak factor. The dimensioning of a treatment facility must take these fluctuations into account and it is recommended that long term variations in wastewater discharge are included as well. Chemical loadings of chemical oxygen demand, total-nitrogen and total-phosphorus were measured using Hach Lange test kits and varied from 412 to 942 PE. Heavy metals were measured in both water and sludge produced from lab scale flocculation using inductive coupled plasma (ICP). Concentrations of cadmium exceeded the limit of 0.8 mg/kg for use on agricultural soil in Danish legislation. Due to this the sludge will most likely have to been landfilled unless the cadmium concentration is reduced.

fields.title: Contaminated sites in Kangerlussuaq, Greenland: Review of the current situation
fields.abstract: With an increasing awareness on environmental sustainability in Greenland, municipal-ities are working towards implementing sustainable solutions in towns and settle-ments. However, traces of former and current polluting activities are widespread in Greenland and might delay the progress. In this study, the former military base of Kangerlussuaq was investigated to (1) analyze the potential of connecting Kangerlus-suaq Airport to the existing sewage network in order to reduce the potential release of heavy metals from deicing activities; (2) describe the impact of historic and current contaminated sites in the settlement; and (3) recommend solutions for remediation of contaminated sites. A literature review revealed heavy metal concentrations above natural background concentrations in the fjord close to the settlement. Low consump-tion of deicing fluids disproves the assumption that the high load of heavy metals are caused by deicing activities. Moreover, it was found that connecting the airport to the sewers, prior to installation of sewage treatment, will have a negative effect on the aquatic environment. A list of 112 contaminated sites in Kangerlussuaq was obtained describing historic and active hot spots in the settlement. During sampling in Kanger-lussuaq, several severe oil pollutions were observed. The sites were concluded to pose a risk to the local environment and human health, thus it is recommended to remediate the sites by excavation and ex-situ treatment.

fields.title: Electrodialytic Remediation of Heavy Metals and Oil in Harbour Sediment, Sisimiut
fields.abstract:
When the fragile environment of the Arctic is exposed to contaminants, it can have
severe consequences for the ecosystems living here. At the same time, the likelihood of
contamination of the Arctic is increasing as a consequence of expanding industries and
climate changes.
The main focus of this study was to investigate the contamination in the sediment in
the inner harbour of Sisimiut, Greenland, with regards to hydrocarbons and the heavy
metals Cd, Cu, Pb and Zn. A characterization of the current state of contamination was
carried out, and ve electrodialytic remediation (EDR) experiments were conducted to
remediate the contaminants from the sediment. The EDR set-up assessed the eect of
respectively electric current and stirring rate in a 2-compartment cell.
The ve experiments were carried out testing a high and a low current (50 mA and
4 mA) combined with a high and a low stirring rate (1300 rpm and 100 rpm). Also,
a middle experiment was carried out, testing a medium high current (23 mA) and a
medium high stirring rate (600 rpm). The experiments were executed on a 7-day basis,
where the pH of the system was regulated daily. ICP-MS was used to measure the
amount of heavy metals in the sediment and in dierent parts of the cell after EDR,
and a GC was used to measure the amount of hydrocarbons.
The results showed concentrations of Cd, Cu, Pb and Zn as high as 0.52 mg Cd/kg,
130 mg Cu/kg, 42.4 mg Pb/kg and 204 mg Zn/kg in the harbour sediment. The hydrocarbon
content representing the oil content was especially high close to the gasoline
station, reaching at its highest a concentration of 473 mg THC/kg sediment. These
investigations showed potential damaging concentrations compared to several quality
criteria. The EDR results conrmed the expected high eciency in regards to remediation
of heavy metals, and a slightly higher inuence by increasing the current than
by increasing the stirring rate was indicated. The highest removal of the heavy metals
were 28 % Cd, 19 % Pb and 66 % Zn at 23 mA and 600 rpm, and 53 % Cu at 50 mA
and 1300 rpm. A large part of the initial content of heavy metals was found in the
liquid phase in the main compartment of the EDR cell. A ltering of the liquid from
the solid phase could therefore improve the remediation signicantly. For remediation
of hydrocarbons, a tendency toward a too fast acidication was shown by the increased
current, resulting in a decreased degradation of oil. The measurements of hydrocarbons
however contained strong uncertainties. An increase of hydrocarbons was found in the
intervals C5-C6, C6-C18, C18-C30 og C30< for all the experiments except the experiment
conducted under 23 mA and 600 rpm.
Improvements of EDR method and more precise assessments of the inuential variables
are needed, if EDR is intended used for remediation of both hydrocarbons and heavy
metals simultaneously. This study suggests a partition of the experiment where hydrocarbons
are rst degraded, after which the heavy metals are removed. This set-up
suggests initiating primarily stirring in the suspension, followed by the application of
current.

fields.title: Isolation and culture of hydrocarbon degrading bacteria from Arctic samples
fields.abstract: Future oil extraction in Arctic areas, could lead to a large scale oil spill, which would result in severe damage of the pristine environments. The existing microbial communities participate in oil degradation, thus these are of interest to investigate. In this study, samples were collected in Arctic environments (Sisimiut, Greenland) and represented an oil polluted harbor and an unpolluted pristine area. The presence of cold tolerant bacterial communities, able to grow in hydrocarbons rich environments, was investigated. Broth enrichments and plating’s were incubated at both 5°C and 20°C. As main carbon sources, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) and more complex hydrocarbons such as diesel and motor oil were used. Several bacterial strains were cultured in artificial seawater media with hydrocarbons added. Bacterial growth was assessed as colony forming units/mL (CFU/mL) and counted after different periods of incubation. The bacterial populations from both the harbor and the pristine area were able to grow in the presence of hydrocarbons. However, since growth was also seen in/on substrates with no hydrocarbon added, it is not known if the hydrocarbons were actually used as sole carbon source. All growth media contained traces of casamino acids that likely served as C-source. A 10 fold increased CFU/mL in 75% of the hydrocarbon containing samples, was observed in growth media with/without casamino acids. Conclusively, the sampled bacterial strains were able to grow in hydrocarbon rich environments. Bacterial strains were isolated from the samples. Overall the PAH's were observed with a 38% increased CFU/mL compared to diesel and motor oil, indicating the challenge of degrading more complex substances as crude oil. Observations in this study indicate, that compared to an oil spill in temperate climates, the bacterial growth rate will be significantly decreased because of the low seawater temperatures and time needed for bacterial adaptation.

fields.title: Investigation of Thermal Performance and Self-ignition of a Highly Insulated Wall Assembly for Greenland
fields.abstract: The extreme cold climate in Greenland and the fact that the building codes are based on Danish standards, results in a high heating demand for buildings in Greenland. In order to overcome the problem, the heat loss of buildings can be reduced by lowering the U-values of the construction. In this article, a wall design with a 450 mm insulation thickness is developed and investigated based on previous studies. An insulation material, which is suitable to the design, and could potentially be produced locally, was chosen in order to lower the expenses for shipping building materials. The insulation material chosen was Papiruld, produced from recycled paper and flame retardants. The thermal performance of the design was determined by an experimental setup in Sisimiut Greenland in the period of November 2015. The studied showed that the theoretical U-value of the wall-section would be 0.08 W/m2K. Settling of the material over time showed to be a problem, creating unforeseen thermal bridges in the design. The insulation material was also investigated in regards to fire safety, as this is an important issue when creating a construction design for living. Spontaneous ignition tests were carried out in the fire lab at DTU Lyngby Denmark. The test showed a risk of self-ignition of the material in a temperature range of 185-200℃. If protected from heat exposure by suitable internal cladding, the insulation could potentially be used in the design. However, this requires further research with the overall construction design.

fields.title: Performance of chemical herders in ice infested waters
fields.abstract: In Situ Burning is an oil spill response technique with a good potential for remote and ice infested waters. Fire resistant containment booms are commonly used to collect and keep the oil slicks thick in open water. However, the presence of ice can make the fire booms’ application more challenging. The herders are chemical surfactants that spread out to form a monolayer on the water surface resulting in compaction and thickening of the oil slick. Therefore, these herding agents could be a good alternative for accidents in ice infested waters. The effectiveness of the herder was studied with respect to the ignition and burning of oil slicks. Specifically, the average slick thickness, the distribution of slicklets on the water surface and the burning efficiency were studied as a function of different ice coverages (0%, 20%, 50%, and 80%). Experiments were performed in an intermediate scale water basin (16 m2) outdoors in Sisimiut, Greenland and in a small scale, indoor laboratory setup (1 m2) at DTU. A predetermined amount of crude oil (approximately 240 mL) was allowed to spread for 30 minutes and afterwards the herding agent was applied (150 μL/m2 oil) in the vicinity of the edges of the water surface, and then allowed to herd the oil for 30 minutes. The average slick thickness of the herded oil reached up to approximately 5.5 mm and the oil slicks could easily be ignited.
